questions.text: If the total body water is 60% of the body weight, what are the proportions of extracellular fluid (ECF) and intracellular fluid (ICF) respectively?
questions.solution:
When expressed as the percentage of body weight 20% of body weight is in ECF (1/3rd of 60%), and 40% of body weight is in ICF (2/3rd of 60%), 

The 60-40-20 rule is: 60% of body weight is water, of which 40% is ICF, and 20% is ECF.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialised compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. It constitutes <1% of TBW (1-2L).
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A child with IgA nephropathy comes for a follow-up. Among the given clinical findings, which of the following would indicate a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In patients with IgA nephropathy, persistent hypertension at follow-up is indicative of poor prognosis. 

IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease) is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Clinically, children and young adults present with gross or microscopic hematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory (synpharyngitic presentation) or gastrointestinal infection.

The progression of the disease is slow and variable. There may be heavy proteinuria, hypertension, and chronic renal failure in severe cases. IgA nephropathy in children is associated with an increased risk of progressive disease developing later in adulthood, prompting the need for careful long-term follow-up.

Indicators of poor prognosis at presentation or follow-up include persistent hypertension, decreased renal function, and significant, increasing, or prolonged proteinuria. Histologic evidence of diffuse mesangial proliferation, extensive glomerular crescents, glomerulosclerosis, and diffuse tubulointerstitial changes (such as inflammation and fibrosis) are correlated with a more severe prognosis.

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

The disease is treated with ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added.

Other options : 

Option B: Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic or prognostic value in IgA nephropathy because they are elevated in only 15% of pediatric patients.

Option C: Serum C3 levels in IgA nephropathy are characteristically normal, and rarely low C3 levels are seen in severe cases.

Option D: A history of recurrent hematuria is common in IgA nephropathy and is not related to prognostication.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes  ______
questions.solution:
Point C denotes the opening of the aortic valve.

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml, called the end-diastolic volume and the diastolic pressure rising to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled “IV” traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled “EW”) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Proprioception is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei, 3 sensory (Mesencephalic, Spinal and Principal Sensory nucleus) and 1 motor. 

NUCLEUS LOCATION FUNCTION
Mesencephalic Nucleus Composed of a column of unipolar nerve cells situated in the midbrain and extends inferiorly into the pons as far as the main sensory nucleus Receives the sensation of proprioception from the muscles of mastication and from the facial and extraocular muscles
Principal sensory nucleus The posterior part of the pons lateral to the motor nucleus

Receives the sensations of touch and pressure from the face
Spinal nucleus Continuous superiorly with the main sensory nucleus and extends inferiorly the whole of the medulla oblongata till the 2nd Cervical Segment Receives the sensation of pain(Option B) and temperature(Option A) from the face and some fibres of touch(Option C)
Motor nucleus The pons medial to the main sensory nucleus Supplies the muscles of mastication, the tensor tympani, the tensor veli palatine, the mylohyoid and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in the STEP approach of WHO?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic assessment is not included in the WHO's STEP approach. 

The STEP approach of WHO is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases(NCD). It helps countries establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

  • Questionnaires contain questions about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 
  • Physical measurements contain blood pressure, height, weight, and waist size
  • Biochemical measurements contain blood glucose, blood lipids, urinary sodium, and creatinine.  

Note: Mental health and suicide are included in optional behavioral risk factors (step 1). Hence, psychological assessment is also included in the STEP approach. 

Related Pearl: Sentinel Surveillance

  • Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.
  • It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.
  • Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.
  • Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: The establishment bearing the following logo would provide services aimed at ______.
questions.solution:
The Suraksha Clinics are for management of sexually transmitted diseases and patients are given color-coded kits.

The kits are

  • Kit 1– grey, for urethra discharge, painful scrotal swelling, and cervicitis.
  • Kit 2– green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3– white, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4– blue, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 5– red, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 6– yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7– black, for inguinal bubo.
  • Kit 8– brown, for anorectal discharge

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: A 32-year-old traveller who was lost in the desert was found after two days. He says he has not consumed food or water for more than 24 hours. His vitals were normal. Which of the following parts of the kidney must have been the site of maximum water reabsorption in this case?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.

The driving force for water reabsorption is a transtubular osmotic gradient established by reabsorption of solutes.

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis shows all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis does not show Birbeck bodies. These bodies are seen in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Birbeck bodies are tennis racket-shaped structures found in the Langerhans cells of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (shown in the image below). Although it can occur in adults, it is seen more commonly in children. Lesions similar to seborrheic eruptions are seen on the back, scalp, and trunk.

The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas: 

  • Schaumann bodies: Inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies: Stellate inclusions in the giant cells

Noncaseating granulomas can also be seen in:

  • Berylliosis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Foreign body granuloma

questions.text:
Mid-term abortion is being planned for a young female. Your consultant decides to use a natural PGE2 drug as an abortifacient. Identify the drug from the following.

PGE2 - Prostaglandin E2
questions.solution:
Dinoprostone is a naturally occurring prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) preparation.

Options A: Dinoprost is a natural PGF2 alpha preparation.

Option B:  Carboprost is a 15-methyl synthetic derivative of PGF2 alpha. It is used as an abortifacient and in refractory PPH.

Option C: Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE1 analogue.

questions.text: Which of the following study designs is used to calculate the point prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The study design that can be used to calculate the point prevalence of a disease is a Cross-sectional study.

The point prevalence of a disease is defined as the number of all current cases at a point in time. It can be calculated using cross-sectional studies. A cross-sectional study Is an observational study used to calculate a disease's distribution and prevalence. Prevalence helps to estimate the magnitude of health/ disease problems in the community and identify potential high-risk populations.

Other options:

Options A & B: A cohort study is an analytical study involving the follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease. It can be used to calculate incidence.

Option D: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention is given to a group of patients participating in the study and compared to another group of patients with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied. It is used to calculate the effect of an intervention.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Workshop

A. Series of lectures on a subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions
2. Symposium B. Incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, and discussions, and may last for half a day to a week.
3. Roleplay C. Series of meetings emphasizing individual work within the group
4. Seminar

D. Dramatization of social situations for health education
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, and discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the labor room. Which of the following parameters would you consider while calculating the APGAR score in a newborn?
  1. Respiratory rate 
  2. Pulse rate 
  3. Muscle tone
  4. Oxygen saturation
  5. Appearance
questions.solution:
The parameters to consider while calculating APGAR score in newborn babies are:

  1. Appearance
  2. Pulse rate (Heart rate)
  3. Grimace
  4. Activity(muscle tone)
  5. Respiratory effort.

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for false positive APGAR score are:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant female presents to Dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image findings are suggestive of chloasma. 

Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and the same facial melanosis in non-pregnant women is called melasma which is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.

Wood's Lamp examination is useful to differentiate the level of pigmentation and therefore the response to treatment. Chloasma self resolves after pregnancy but melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like kligman's triple combination(topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream), hydroquinone, kojic acid, chemical peels.

Other options :

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus is characterised by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option B: Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, and chin. It is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years.

Option C: Rosacea mainly involves the convexities of the face and presents as erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks.

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with killing bacteria and viruses?
questions.solution:
Lysosomes contain hydrolytic enzymes and are associated with killing bacteria and viruses. 

Lysosomes  are membrane-bound organelles broken off from the Golgi apparatus, containing roughly 40 different acid hydrolases (enzymes that function best in acidic pH ≤5). These hydrolases include proteases, nucleases, lipases, glycosidases, phosphatases, and sulfatases.

Lysosomal enzymes provide an intracellular digestive system that digests damaged cellular structures, food particles ingested by the cells, and foreign particles like bacteria and viruses. The membrane around the lysosomes prevents the hydrolytic enzymes from being in contact with the other substances in the cell and prevents them from being digested. 

When an enzyme is congenitally absent, the cell becomes engorged with the material the enzyme normally degrades. This leads to lysosomal diseases e.g Gaucher disease is caused due to a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

Related Pearl: Lysosomal storage diseases

Lysosomal Storage Diseases Enzyme-deficient
Sphingolipidoses
Gaucher disease Glucocerebrosidase
Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A
Fabry disease α-galactosidase A
Krabbe disease

Galactocerebrosidase

(Galactosylceramidase)
Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase
Mucopolysaccharidoses  
Hurler syndrome α-L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome Iduronate-2-sulfatase
Others:
Pompe disease Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered the best indicators of air pollution?
  1. Sulfur dioxide
  2. Lead
  3. Carbon monoxide
  4. Smoke
  5. Suspended particles
questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles (1, 4, and 5). 

These indicators are monitored daily and their results are reported to a central agency.

Air pollution is the presence of gases and particulate matter in the atmosphere that affect human health and safety. It is also injurious to animals and vegetation. Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide
  • Smoke or soiling index
  • Grit and dust measurement (suspended particles)
  • Co-efficient of haze 
  • Air pollution index 

Air pollution in India is monitored by the National Air Quality Monitoring Program (NAMP). This program is sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). 

Under the NAMP, four air pollutants are regularly monitored. They are sulfur dioxide (SO2), oxides of nitrogen such as NO2, respirable suspended particulate matter (RSPM/ PM10), and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). Monitoring of meteorological parameters like wind speed and direction, relative humidity, and temperature have also been included with the monitoring of air quality. This monitoring is carried out twice a week. 

The health effects of air pollution can be immediate or delayed. Immediate effects include acute bronchitis and suffocation. Delayed adverse effects are carcinoma of the lung and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

  • The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.
  • Air pollutants:
Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide From incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulphur dioxide Colorless gas with a sharp odor. Results from combustion of sulphur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc. It is one of the main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources.
Carbon dioxide Increase in global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog.
Cadmium Results from volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc.
Hydrogen sulphide Produced in waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc.
Ozone Ground level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen  Most common form is nitric oxide. Produced from coal burning, road traffic and electricity generation. Affects lungs adversely.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Produced by incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc. PAHs are carcinogenic and mutagenic.
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter. Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon and water.
  • Common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, PAHs, nitrogen and sulphur oxides, pesticides, asbestos, lead, radon and other biological pollutants. Most these are from coal or fuel combustion. Pollutants like radon, lead, asbestos, etc. are from construction materials, paints and demolition.
  • Effects of indoor air pollution:
    • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
    • Stroke
    • Ischemic heart disease
    • COPD
    • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
    • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight
  • Indicators of air pollution:
    • Sulphur dioxide is one of the best indicators of air pollution
    • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
    • Grit and dust measurement are another indicator of air pollution
    • Co-efficient of haze is a factor used in assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosol in air
    • Air pollution index is an arbitrary index which takes into account one or more pollutants as a measure of pollution severity
    • Suspended particle matter (SPM) is another indicator widely used
  • In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: The injury to the common peroneal nerve due to a blow on the lateral aspect of fibula is likely to result in all of the following features except ________

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the dorsum of foot
Loss of extension of great toe
Loss of sensation over lateral border of foot

questions.solution:
Loss of sensation over the lateral border of the foot is not seen in the injury to the common peroneal nerve because this area is innervated by the sural nerve which is a branch of the tibial nerve.

The common peroneal nerve is most commonly injured at the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. Injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop, loss of eversion, loss of extension of toes and sensory loss along the anterior and lateral side of the leg, dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe.

Note: Ankle reflex is preserved in common peroneal nerve palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about thoracolumbar fascia?

choices.text: In the lumbar region it is in 4 layers
In the thoraic region it is attatched medially to the vertebrae
The anterior,posterior and middle layer join to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
In the lumbar region, the fascia consists of 3 layers - anterior, middle, and posterior layer.

The thoracolumbar fascia is a complex arrangement of multiple fascial layers in the thoracolumbar region. This fascia encloses the paraspinal muscles, quadratus lumborum muscle, and lattisimus dorsi muscle.

Thoracic region: The thoracolumbar fascia provides a thin fibrous covering for the extensor muscles of the vertebral column. Medially it is attached to the spines of the thoracic vertebrae and laterally to the angles of the ribs

Lumbar region: It is in three layers:

  • Anterior
    • Medially - the anterior surface of the lumbar transverse processes.
    • Laterally - blends with the middle layer at the lateral border of the quadratus lumborum.
    • Superiorly - lateral arcuate ligament and tip of Transverse process L1 to 12th rib.
    • Inferiorly - the inner lip of the iliac crest and the iliolumbar ligament.
  • Middle
    • Medially - tips of the lumbar transverse processes and inter-transverse ligaments.
    • Laterally - blends with the anterior layer at the lateral border of the quadratus lumborum.
    • Superiorly - lower border of the 12th rib and lumbocostal ligament.
    • Inferiorly - the intermediate area of the iliac crest.
  • Posterior
    • Medially - lumbar and sacral spines and interspinous ligaments.
    • Laterally - blends with the middle layer at the lateral border of the erector spinae.
    • Superiorly - back of thorax - lumbar vertebral spines.
    • Inferiorly - outer lip of the iliac crest

The posterior and middle layers unite to form a tough raphe at the lateral margin of erector spinae, and at the lateral border of quadratus lumborum, they are joined by the anterior layer to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis.

Function:

  • The attachments have a role in lifting and load transfer ,although controversial.
  • They contain nociceptive nerve endings that may be responsible for back pain due to injury to the area and also impaired proprioceptive signalling.

questions.text: During a cholera outbreak, you are asked to map the geographical distribution of the disease. What is the best method of doing this?
questions.solution:
Dot-density maps are the best way to plot the geographical distribution of diseases.

The image given below shows a dot-density map of London that was plotted during the 1854 outbreak of cholera.

A dot-density map was used by Dr John Snow when a large outbreak of cholera occurred in London in 1854. Initially, it was believed that bad smells/ air from rotting organic matter spread the disease. He demonstrated the link between contaminated drinking water and cholera. He mapped the disease and identified the source to be a contaminated public water pump in Broad Street, London. 

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A young male patient was suspected to have a seminoma of the testis. The mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. Which among the following findings is most likely to be seen microscopically?

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
Microscopically, seminomas show a fried egg appearance of cells. This refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (around 50% of GCTs). It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. It is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells. The image of Reinke crystals is shown below.

Option D: Derivatives of all three germ layers like islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of the thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text: A young girl is brought by their parents due to concern about her height. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high, and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point towards Laron dwarfism. 

It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to a mutation in the GH receptor. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features like those seen in pituitary dwarfism.

Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low.

Patients with Laron syndrome present with features such as:

  • Growth failure
  • Small head circumference
  • Characteristic facies with saddle nose and prominent forehead
  • Short limb length compared with trunk
  • Osteopenia
  • Obesity
  • In some cases mild to moderately impaired intellect may be seen

Other options

Option A: In Turner's syndrome, loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and decreased utilization.

Option B: Pituitary dwarfism is a condition with GH deficiency.

Option D: Maternal deprivation dwarfism is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules this out.

questions.text:
In response to an increase in the GFR, the area marked 4 demonstrates an increase in the rate of Na+ reabsorption. This phenomenon is called _____________.

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate
questions.solution:
In the given image, the area marked 4 is the cells of the proximal convoluted tubule which are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels.
 
This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

For example, if the GFR increases from 125 to 150 ml/min, the absolute rate of proximal tubular reabsorption also increases from about 81 ml/min (65% of GFR) to approximately 97.5 ml/min (65% of GFR). Therefore, even when the total rate of reabsorption and filtered load rise, the proportion of GFR reabsorbed in the proximal tubule stays relatively constant, at around 65%.

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

Other options: 

Option A: Renal splay is the deviation in the actual renal threshold from the calculated renal threshold. If all the tubules in the nephron worked at a given time, then the renal threshold would be 300mg/dL, that is, 375 mg/min (TmG-transport maximum) divided by 125 mL/min (GFR). However, the actual renal threshold is 200mg/dL. This is because, at a given time, not all tubules are reabsorbing the glucose. 

Option B: Renal autoregulation maintains the renal blood flow to almost a constant level irrespective of arterial perfusion pressure within physiological limits. It is due to the action of vascular smooth muscles in renal afferent arteriole, which respond to stretch caused by blood pressure. This relative constancy of GFR and renal blood flow is referred to as autoregulation. 

Option C: Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) changes the rate of filtration and tubular flow by reflex vasoconstriction or dilatation of the afferent arteriole. It is mediated by specialized cells in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle called the macula densa that act as sensors of solute concentration and tubular flow rate.

questions.text: The muscle given below passes through the sciatic foramen. Identify the muscle:
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in the image is piriformis.

Origin:

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion: Greater trochanter of the femur.

Action:

  1. Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
  2. Abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterised by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle

The following image shows different muscles and of the pelvis and their attachments

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramen

Structures passing through the Greater Sciatic Foramen

The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis, it fills the foramen almost completely and is the key muscle of the region.

Structures passing above the piriformis

Structures passing below the piriformis

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the Lesser Sciatic Foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following viruses shows genetic change similar to the influenza virus?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus exhibits genetic reassortment/antigenic drift similar to that of the influenza virus.

Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. 11 segments of double-stranded RNA constitute the genome. Influenza viruses have a linear, segmented, single-stranded RNA. Reassortment of the genome occurs readily due to the presence of this segmented RNA.

Other options:

Option B - Adenovirus contains double-stranded DNA. It has icosahedral symmetry, with structures known as fibers extruding from the vertices. 

Option C - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

Option D - Rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae are bullet-shaped viruses, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: During a clinical assessment, a neurologist stimulates a specific structure to evaluate the sensory supply from a cranial nerve. Which cranial nerve's sensory function is being assessed by touching the highlighted structure in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given sagittal section of the head and neck is the uvula. The sensory supply by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)  is tested in this case.

Innervation of the soft palate:

  • General sensation - Lesser palatine nerve(branch of maxillary nerve) and the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve 
  • Taste sensation - Lesser palatine nerve.
  • Secretomotor supply -Lesser palatine nerve via postganglionic fibres from the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • Motor supply - Pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve (except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

Pharyngeal plexus: The nerve supply of the pharynx is mainly from the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form it. (It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion) The vagus nerve provides the motor supply and the glossopharyngeal nerve provides the sensory supply.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibres to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior third of the tongue.
  • Motor fibres to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibres for the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

Nerve supply by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve:

  • All the muscles of the soft palate (except tensor veli palatini - supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve)
  • All the muscles of the pharynx(except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
BCG vaccine is primarily used against tuberculosis disease. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. Hence, option D is not true. 

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation (option B) than the liquid vaccine. Currently, the vaccine is distributed in the freeze-dried form because of better storage qualities. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth (option A) and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally (option C) just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

A papule develops at the vaccination site after 2-3 weeks. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Usually, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include prolonged severe ulceration at the vaccination site, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infection. It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old unimmunized child presented to pediatric OPD with fever, sore throat, and difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils as shown. Which of the following is not a selective medium for the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an unimmunized child with a history of fever, difficulty in swallowing, and a thick whitish membrane over the tonsils points towards the diagnosis of diphtheria. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched (not selective) medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria

Enriched medium: When a basal medium is added with additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg, it is called enriched medium. Eg. Blood agar is prepared by adding 5-10% of sheep blood to the molten nutrient agar at 45°C.

Advantage of Loeffler's serum slope

  • Rapid growth(6-8 hrs)
  • The best medium for metachromatic granule production

Disadvantage: As it is not a selective medium if incubated beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals also.

Selective medium: Solid media that allow certain organisms(pathogens) to grow and inhibit others (normal flora). Eg. LJ medium for isolation of M. tuberculosis, TCBS for vibrio species.

Selective media for Corynebacterium diphtheria

  • Potassium tellurite agar
  • Cystine-tellurite Blood Agar
  • Tinsdale medium

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5?
questions.solution:
Step 5 in the given life cycle shows the integration of the viral DNA into the host genome. Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and is active against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. It can be used in adults and children >1 month old. 

It is advised for patients to consume antacids and sucralfate, 6 hours before or 2 hours after raltegravir intake.

It may cause headaches, nausea, weakness and fatigue. Rarely, it can lead to drug reactions with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome.

The steps involved in the lifecycle of HIV as given in the image are described as follows:

  • Step 1: Binding of HIV-1 to the cell membrane of a CD4+ cell
  • Step 2: HIV-1 enters the cell via interaction with the membrane glycoproteins
  • Step 3: Reverse transcription of the viral genetic material using the virus' reverse transcriptase enzyme
  • Step 4: The HIV-1 genome travels into the nucleus
  • Step 5: The viral genome integrates into the host's DNA through the integrase enzyme
  • Step 6: The HIV-1 proviral genome undergoes transcription with the host DNA
  • Step 7: The viral messenger RNA (mRNA) undergoes translation to produce new viral proteins
  • Steps 8 and 9: Assembly and maturation of the virion

Other options:

Option B: Enfuvirtide acts at step 2 in the given image. It blocks gp41 of the cell membrane and blocks the entry of the virus into the cell. It prevents the free viral particles from invading new CD4+ cells. It is effective against HIV-1.

Option C: Tenofovir acts at step 3 in the given image. It is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against HIV-1,2 and hepatitis B infections. It is used in adults and children >2 years old. It can also be used for pre-exposure prophylaxis. 

Option D: Zidovudine also acts at step 3 in the given image. It is an NRTI and is effective against HIV-1,2 and Human T-cell Lymphoma Virus (HTLV). It can be used in adults and children. It can also be used to prevent mother-to-child transmission.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal bloating and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination revealed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a characteristic boiled cabbage odor. Lab results showed elevated transaminases and succinylacetone levels. What is the recommended treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis) and correct answer is all of the above. It is treated by a combination of nitisone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of toxic metabolites, primarily fumarylacetoacetate and maleylacetoacetate.

They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia and vitamin D resistant rickets.

Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia. Treatment includes nitisone which acts by inhibiting 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD), an enzyme involved in the tyrosine catabolic pathway and prevents the accumulation of toxic metabolites mentioned above. Dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine is also helpful.

Note: A boiled cabbage odour can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: A patient presenting with chronic gout has been prescribed a drug that inhibits xanthine oxidase.  Which among the following drugs is it?
questions.solution:
Febuxostat is a selective inhibitor of xanthine oxidase thereby reducing xanthine and uric acid. 

Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors indicated in the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients suffering from gout. Febuxostat is more potent than allopurinol. 

The adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, diarrhea, joint pain, and rash. A flare in the gout attack can be seen during the initiation of therapy due to a decrease in serum uric acid levels that results in the mobilization of uric acid from tissue deposits.

Other options:

Option A: Colchicine is an antimitotic drug that is used in the treatment of acute gout. It acts by inhibiting microtubule and spindle formation. Side effects are nausea, vomiting, myelosuppression, aplastic anemia, and rhabdomyolysis.

Option B: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acids by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubule. It is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation.

Option C: Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive. It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.text: According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than _________.
questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than 1000.

The Factories Act, 1948 states the following regarding safety and welfare measures:

  • > 1000 workers – there should be a safety officer
  • > 500 workers – there should be a welfare officer
  • > 250 workers – a canteen should be provided
  • > 30 female workers- a crèche should be provided

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.
  • Adolescents between 15 – 18 years
    • Can be employed  only in certain industries and  work between 6 AM – 7 PM
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: An observer notes that the maternal deaths that happened in hospital deliveries in the past year are higher than maternal deaths in home deliveries. He concludes that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals. This is an example of :
questions.solution:
The given association is an association that appears due to improper comparison. It may lead to a spurious association or an association when none actually existed.

Here, maternal mortality is likely to have been higher in-hospital deliveries compared to home deliveries because hospitals attract women at high risk for delivery because of their special equipment and expertise, whereas this is not necessarily the case with home deliveries. When confounding factors and selection biases are not accounted for, it may result in incorrect conclusions regarding the association. So the conclusion that homes are a safer place for delivery than hospitals is likely to have been spurious or artifactual.

The association can be broadly grouped under three headings:

  • Spurious association
  • Indirect association
  • Direct (causal) association
    • One-to-one causal association
    • Multifactorial causation

Other options:

Option A: Direct (causal) association- Two variables are stated to be causally related (AB) if a change in A is followed by a change in B. When factor A is present, disease B must result. Measles is one such disease in which such a relation exists.

Option B: Indirect association- The indirect association is an association between a variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable. 

Option D: Multifactorial causation is seen in non-communicable diseases or conditions (e.g., Coronary heart disease) where the etiology is multifactorial.

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Categories according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Definition  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥ 1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥ 1.   Same as category 2

questions.text: An old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells, and culture on MacConkey agar showed the following. Which organism is involved here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and growth of lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar suggest a diagnosis of urinary tract infection by Escherichia coli. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium:

  • Lactose fermenters - Escherichia, Klebsiella
  • Late lactose fermenters - Shigella sonnei
  • Non-lactose fermenters- Salmonella species, Shigella species

The image below shows lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Mnemonic to remember non-lactose fermenters: (SPY PSM)

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia- late fermenter
  • Shigella (except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

questions.text: Identify the given histology slide:
questions.solution:
The above image shows pancreatic islet cells. Islet of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers, and containing numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The image given below shows the histology of the pancreas.

The islets of Langerhans contain four major and two minor cell types:

Four main types are β, α, δ, and PP (pancreatic polypeptide) cells:

  • α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
  • β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 
  • δ or D cells- scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin
  • PP cells- are present in islets and also in the exocrine pancreas. They secrete a pancreatic polypeptide, which exerts several gastrointestinal effects, such as stimulation of secretion of gastric and intestinal enzymes and inhibition of intestinal motility. 

Minor cell types:

  • D1 cells secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), a hormone that induces glycogenolysis and hyperglycemia. It also stimulates gastrointestinal fluid secretion and causes secretory diarrhea.
  • Enterochromaffin cells synthesize serotonin and are the source of pancreatic tumors that cause carcinoid syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. The structure of lymph nodes consists of an outer cortex and inner medulla. The cortex contains an aggregation of B-lymphocytes (primary follicles) and quiescent secondary follicles with a pale central germinal center.

The inner medulla consists of medullary cords (lymphocytes and plasma cells) and medullary sinuses. Between the cortex and medulla, there is an ill-defined zone called the paracortex, which contains T lymphocytes.

The image given below shows the histology of the lymph node. 

Option B: Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries. The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option C: Spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ. It contains round white pulp surrounded by red pulp. The white pulp is made up of aggregations of lymphocytes that surround a small artery or arterioles.

The red pulp is a modified lymphoid tissue infiltrated with all the cells of circulating blood. It is like a sponge permeated by spaces (splenic sinusoids) lined by reticular cells. The zone of red pulp immediately surrounding white pulp is the marginal zone. This zone has a rich network of sinusoids.

The image given below shows the histology of the spleen.

questions.text: What is the mode of inheritance of Huntington's disease?
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease is an autosomal-dominant inherited disorder.

Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and is associated with the degeneration of striatal neurons.

Features such as chorea and dementia are commonly seen in these patients 

The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioral changes.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with pallor and fatigue. Investigations revealed the following: Hb, 5 gm %; MCH, 24; low MCV; leukocytes, 11,000/uL, and platelets, 5 lakhs. The iron profile showed low ferritin and high TIBC. What is the diagnosis?

MCV : Mean corpuscular volume (normal MCV is 82–96 fl)

MCH: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (normal MCH is 27–33 pg/cell)

TIBC: Total iron binding capacity (normal TIBC is 240 to 450 mcg/dL)
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old woman, presenting with fatigue and pallor along with her investigation results are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia (IDA).

IDA is an example of microcytic hypochromic anemia. The causes of IDA can be inadequate diet, impaired reabsorption, increased requirement, and increased blood loss.

The manifestations of IDA depend upon the underlying cause. In general, IDA presents with koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorption, and pica (craving for consumption of non-edible materials)

Peripheral smears show small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic (reduced MCV) and hypochromic (enlarged zone of central pallor). Poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of elongated red cells, known as pencil cells. Target cells can be found in cases of severe IDA.

Diagnosis is mainly my laboratory studies. The typical findings in IDA are:

  • Low hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Low serum iron and ferritin
  • Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
  • Hepcidin is low (decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis)
  • IDA is treated by giving oral and parenteral preparations of iron or packed cell transfusion depending upon the severity of the anemia.

Option A: Megaloblastic anemia is defined by a high MCV

Option C: Anemia of chronic disease would present with normal to high ferritin and low TIBC

Option D: Sideroblastic anemia has high ferritin and normal TIBC

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

MCV Decreased Markedly Decreased May be low or normal
RBC count <5 million/µL >5 million/µL Normal
Mentzer Index ≥13 <13 N/A
RDW-CV(%) >15 <15 Normal/Increased

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: It occurs due to the presence of glucuronidase
Phototherapy is not required in all cases
It occurs due to decreased milk intake

questions.solution:
Breast milk jaundice is not due to decreased milk intake. It is due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

  • Early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth) 
  • Due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. (Breastfeeding failure jaundice)
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

Breast milk jaundice (BMJ)

  • Late-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week
  • Due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk (etiology not entirely clear).
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases.

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

 Predominantly Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Excess production of bilirubin

  

Hemolytic anemias

Biliary tract obstruction

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., pernicious anemia, thalassemia)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Impaired bilirubin conjugation

Genetic deficiency of UGT1A1 activity (Crigler-Najjar syndrome types I and II)

  

Gilbert syndrome

  

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.text: Which of the following cells act as slow-adapting touch receptors?
questions.solution:
Slow adapting touch receptors are Merkel cells.

Merkel cells also known as Haascheiben cells, Merkel-Ranvier cells or tactile epithelial cells, are oval-shaped mechanoreceptors essential for light touch sensation and found in the skin of vertebrates.

  • They are seen among the Basal keratinocytes and contain desmosomes.
  • They are abundant in the highly sensitive skin like that of the fingertips in humans.
  • They make synaptic contacts with somatosensory afferent nerve fibers.
  • Although uncommon, these cells may become malignant and form a Merkel cell carcinoma — an aggressive and difficult to treat skin cancer.

Other options :

Option A : Meissner corpuscle are present in the papillary dermis. These corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors particularly sensitive to the movement of objects over the skin's surface and low-frequency vibrations. Their acute sensitivity plays a crucial role in tasks such as reading Braille text.

Option B : Pacinian corpuscles respond to fast vibration and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors. They are large encapsulated nerve endings with concentric layers of connective tissue that have an onion-skin appearance and are present in the dermis. 

Option C : Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious discharge from the nose is suggestive of Hurler's disease.

It is the severe form of mucopolysaccharidoses type 1 (MPS 1), an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in α-L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. The child usually presents between 6 and 24 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features (shown below), corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

Most patients have recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Radiograph shows skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex - thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged and trabeculated diaphyses of the long bones with irregular metaphysis and epiphysis.

Macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella, premature closure of lambdoid sagittal sutures, and shallow orbits are seen with disease progression. Obstructive airway disease, cardiac complications, and respiratory infections are the common causes of death. 

The image below shows the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges. 

Other options:

Option B: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and renal anomalies. It is associated with an increased risk of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal cortical carcinoma.

Option C: Proteus syndrome is a disturbance of cellular growth involving ectodermal and mesodermal tissues, caused by mutation in the AKT1 gene. They present with hemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous cutaneous lesions, thickening of the bone, and excessive growth of muscles.

Option D: A child with untreated congenital hypothyroidism may have stunted growth, short extremities, narrow palpebral fissures, swollen eyelids, depressed nasal bridge, thick broad protruded tongue, and short and thick neck, dry and scaly skin. 

Related Pearl: Lysosomal storage diseases

questions.text: A cyanotic newborn is suspected of having congenital heart disease. He has an increased left ventricular impulse and a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border. ECG shows left axis deviation and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of clinical cyanosis in combination with left-axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) noted on the electrocardiogram are suggestive of tricuspid atresia.

Other points in favor:

  • Increased left ventricular impulse (in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, in which an increased right ventricular impulse).
  • Holosystolic murmurs are audible along the left sternal border (due to associated ventricular septal defect).

Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of the tricuspid valve. So, blood cannot flow directly from the right atrium to the right ventricle, and the following associated defects are necessary for survival:

  • Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle
  • There is a hypoplastic right ventricle.

Other options:

Option B and D: Truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot and - The ECG demonstrates right axis deviation (RAD) and evidence of RVH.

Option A: Transposition of great arteries- ECG is usually normal, showing the neonatal right-sided dominant pattern.

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease
