questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the portal triad of the liver?
questions.solution:
Hepatic vein does not form part of the portal triad.

Portal canals are present at the angular intervals at the periphery of each hepatic lobule. They are filled with connective tissue and form a connective tissue network across the entire liver substance.

Each ‘canal’ consists of

  • A branch of the portal vein
  • A branch of the hepatic artery
  • An interlobular bile duct.

These three structures collectively form a portal triad.

The image given below shows a cross-section of the normal hepatic tissue showing the portal triad.

questions.text: Staphylococcus aureus was isolated from the sputum culture of an elderly male suspected to have hospital-acquired pneumonia. You perform the Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method to check if the S.aureus strain is methicillin-resistant. Which is the culture medium used in this test?
questions.solution:
Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar is used in Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method of antibiotic sensitivity testing. 

To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E–test (Epsilometer)

 The image below shows the Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method.

Other options:

Option A: Potassium Tellurite Agar is an indicator medium where potassium tellurite is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

Option C: Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S.

An image of Wilson and Blair's medium is given below-

Option D: Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria.

An image of skirrow's medium is given below-

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. Which of the following drugs is best suited for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The mechanism that causes headaches in this patient, who stopped taking clonidine, is rebound hypertension. Amongst the given drugs, phentolamine is best suited for the control of hypertension due to clonidine withdrawal.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • Clonidine withdrawal
  • Short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • Limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist and a centrally-acting antihypertensive agent. It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic α2 receptors in the vasomotor center in the brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension, restlessness, and sympathetic overactivity. Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also cause impotency and constipation. Phentolamine is used for the control of hypertension due to clonidine withdrawal.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is also a non-selective alpha antagonist but has irreversible action. Side effects are postural hypotension, palpitation, nasal blockage, miosis, and inhibition of ejaculation. It is used primarily in pheochromocytoma, and occasionally in peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. It is a potent antihyper­tensive but is not used as a first-line drug because fluid retention and tolerance gradually develop with monotherapy. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect).

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases heart rate, force of contraction, and cardiac output. It reduces blood pressure on prolonged administration. It has mem­brane stabilizing (Na+ channel blocking) properties and is a potent local anesthetic. It also reduces the secretion of aqueous humor.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought for complaints of short stature. His bone age is greater than his chronological age. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with bone age greater than his chronological age is likely to have precocious puberty.

Precocious puberty is an early onset of puberty and secondary sexual characteristics in children. It can lead to an early height spurt followed by premature epiphyseal fusion and ultimate short stature.

The relationship between bone age and chronological age is summarised below

  • Bone age = chronological age in familial short stature
  • Bone age > chronological age in precocious puberty
  • Bone age < chronological age in other causes like constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes. 

Other options:

Option B: Children with constitutional delay are normal during the first year and fall behind till 3 years, after which the velocity becomes normal. Bone age is lower than chronological age(corresponds to the height age). The onset of puberty is also delayed and they achieve a normal final height. History of delayed puberty and delayed height spurt is usually present in one or both parents.

Option C: Children with Familial short stature have normal according to their own genetic potential determined by the parent's height. The body proportion is appropriate and bone age equals the chronological age with normal growth velocity. They achieve puberty at an appropriate age and their final height is within their target range. 

Option D: Children with growth hormone deficiency have bone age lower than chronological age and other signs like crowding of mid-facial structures, and depressed nasal bridge.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness.  A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so a periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Option C - Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores. 

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins serves as a carrier for one carbon atom?
questions.solution:
The vitamin serving as a carrier for one carbon atom is folic acid.

Methylenetetrahydrofolate receives one-carbon atoms from donors such as serine, glycine, and histidine, which can be transferred to various substrates in biochemical pathways, such as during the synthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and methylation reactions.

Folic acid deficiency leads to megaloblastic anaemia, homocysteinemia and neural tube defect (spina bifida, anencephaly).

The flowchart below describes the sources and utilization of one carbon atom.

Note: The major point of entry for one-carbon fragments, in one-carbon metabolism, is methylenetetrahydrofolate.

Other options :

Option A: Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, is a water-soluble vitamin. Its active forms are FMN (flavin mononucleotide) and FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide). Glutathione reductase is a FAD-containing enzyme (flavoenzyme). Hence, riboflavin deficiency can be detected by measuring erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

Option B: Niacin/ vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD(Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and NADP(Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate). Its deficiency occurs in carcinoid syndrome (all the tryptophan is converted to serotonin), and hartnup disease (defective absorption of tryptophan from the intestine and kidney). 

Option D: Pantothenic acid is vitamin B5. Its active factor is coenzyme A. Its deficiency causes burning feet syndrome. Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency include GI disturbances, paraesthesia, muscle cramps, and ataxia.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given an intravenous drug, and later, he developed abnormal movements. Which of the following can be used to treat him?
questions.solution:
The development of abnormal movements following an anti-emetic injection suggests that the antiemetic used in this case is probably metoclopramide. Benzhexol should be used in the management of this patient. 

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist used as a prokinetic and anti-emetic agent. It can produce extrapyramidal side effects and dystonia is seen acutely following intravenous injections. Anticholinergics like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) are used in the management of these side effects. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting anticholinergic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

Acute dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by sudden, involuntary, and sustained muscle contractions, often leading to abnormal postures or repetitive movements.  It occurs after intravenous administration, while Parkinsonian-like symptoms develop weeks after therapy. It is managed with the discontinuation of metoclopramide and with anticholinergics or antihistaminics. Irreversible tardive dyskinesia can occur with chronic treatment.

Other adverse effects:

It can cause galactorrhea by its dopamine antagonism. Methemoglobinemia can occur if used in infants.

Other options:

Option A: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is a muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the management of motion sickness and vomiting.

Option B: Cyproheptadine is an H1 receptor antagonist used in the management of various allergy-related conditions like allergic rhinitis, anaphylaxis, urticaria, etc.

Option C: Levodopa is the precursor of dopamine and it is given in combination with carbidopa for the management of parkinsonism.

questions.text: The enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is __________.
questions.solution:
The enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is glucose 6-phosphatase.

A decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is seen in the fasting state, where there is the activation of gluconeogenesis and inhibition of glycolysis to conserve glucose and redirect it toward critical functions.

Among the given options, only glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme of gluconeogenesis and is therefore activated. Glucokinase, hexokinase and phosphofructokinase are irreversible enzymes of glycolysis and are inhibited in the fasting state.

Other options :

Option A: Glucokinase, primarily found in the liver and pancreatic β-cells, is activated by insulin. Therefore a decrease in the insulin: glucagon ratio results in lower insulin levels, which in turn inactivates glucokinase and inhibits glycolysis.

Option B: Hexokinase is an enzyme in the glycolytic pathway that helps regulate intracellular glucose levels by catalyzing the initial step of glucose metabolism, the phosphorylation of glucose inside the cell. It becomes activated when the insulin: glucagon ratio rises. However, since the ratio is decreasing in this case, the enzyme will not be activated, thus inhibiting glycolysis.

Option C: Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme of glycolysis and is necessary for the ATP-dependent conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-diphosphate. It is insulin insulin-dependent enzyme and since the insulin: glucagon ratio is decreasing, the enzyme is inactivated.

The following image shows the pathway of glycolysis and the enzymes involved.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is:
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Drinking water should not contain any pathogenic organisms or bacteria indicative of faecal contamination. The primary bacterial indicator used to assess this is the coliform group of organisms. This is because they are present abundantly in the human intestine and can be easily detected by culture methods. 

The presumptive coliform test can be done by the multiple tube method or membrane filtration techniques. In the multiple-tube method, the water to be tested is inoculated into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These tubes are then incubated for 48 hours and examined. The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to other organisms. The presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed. McConkey's lactose bile salt broth with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator is used as the media. Escherichia coli or thermotolerant coliform bacteria should not be detected in any 100 ml sample. 

In samples of chlorinated water, confirmation of the presumptive test is necessary. This is done by subculturing the positive tubes in two tubes of brilliant green bile broth. It is based on the fact that E.Coli is the only coliform that can produce gas from lactose at 44°C.

Supplementary indicator organisms include fecal streptococci and sulfite-reducing clostridia. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters

 

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, there should be no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU for household drinking water.  Expressed in nephelometric turbidity units (NTU). It describes the cloudiness of water. >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye. <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, there should be no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU. Expressed in true color units (TCU). >15 TCU is detectable by naked eye. 
Taste and odor No health based guideline value has been proposed. It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. The cause must be investigated.
Temperature No health based guideline value has been proposed. Cool water is generally more palatable. High water temperature may enhance the growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters

  Guideline values Comments
Ammonia No health based guideline value has been proposed as it occurs in drinking water at concentrations well below those of health concern. Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium 0.9 mg/l There is very less evidence that aluminium in drinking water causes toxic effects.
Arsenic 0.01 mg/l Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride 250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears. Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/litre. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper 2 mg/l Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects and other adverse effects in people without normal copper homeostasis.
Fluoride 1.5 mg/l Above this guideline value, there is risk of dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis. Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre. A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent against methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects in susceptible populations  This guideline
value is based on the absence of adverse health effects (methaemoglobinaemia
and thyroid effects) at concentrations below 50 mg/L in epidemiological studies.
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent against methemoglobinemia in infants and the general population. Bottle-fed infant are at higher risk.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5. ______
Lead 0.01 mg/l The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury 0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury Nephrotoxicity is the main effect of mercury toxicity.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Benzo(a)pyrene at 0.0007 mg/l They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic.
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give unacceptable taste. _________
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable. TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • They include a range of aerobic and facultative anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming bacilli capable of fermenting lactose to acid or aldehyde at 35 to 37 degree Celsius within 24 hours. They include fecal and environmental organisms from wide genera.
    • E. coli and thermotolerant coliforms are a subset of the total coliform groups and they ferment lactose at 44 – 45 degrees Celsius and have the ability to produce indole.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci:
      • They are used as an indicator of fecal pollution.
      • Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens:
      • They are spore-forming organisms which are resistant to many disinfection methods.
      • They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination.
      • Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process and of the presence of other contaminants in the water.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts are indicators of disinfection and distribution of water. It measures a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidences of fecal contamination of water.

 

IV) Radiological aspects

  • Becquerel (Bq) is the unit used for radioactivity.
  • In the case of drinking water, the concentration of radioactivity is referred to as Bq/litre.
  • Proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has a report showing HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 22 mEq/L.

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulfate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] - [Cl− ]

Substituting the values = 145−23−100= 22 mEq/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mEq/L.

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery (RCA) except _____

choices.text: RCA diameter is less than left coronary artery
RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus
RCA gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conal artery is the first branch of RCA

questions.solution:
The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right coronary artery. 

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus (right coronary sinus) of the ascending aorta. (Option B) It passes anteriorly and descends vertically in the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. On reaching the inferior margin, it turns posteriorly and continues in the sulcus on to the diaphragmatic surface and the base of the heart.

The diameter of the right coronary artery is less than that of the left coronary artery. (Option A)

The right conal artery is, usually the first branch of the right coronary artery. (Option D)

questions.text: A child who is a victim under the POCSO Act has been brought to the forensic medicine department for age estimation. The X-ray image of the hand is provided below. What is the likely age of the child?
questions.solution:
Based on the x-ray image of the child provided, the child's age is likely to be 13 years.

In the given X-ray image of the wrist and hand, all the carpal bones are seen. The lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal has not united with the shaft. This suggests that the age of the child is between 8 to 15 years.

Additionally, the presence of the hook of the hamate in the radiograph suggests that the age is between 13-14 years.

questions.text: Which amino acid, when substituted for alanine, would raise the UV absorbance of a protein at 280 nm?
questions.solution:
Replacing alanine with tryptophan will increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength.

To increase the UV absorbance of a protein at a wavelength of 280 nm, the amino acid alanine should be replaced with an amino acid that has an aromatic side chain. Aromatic amino acids, such as tryptophan (maximum absorption), tyrosine and phenylalanine absorb strongly at 280 nm due to the presence of conjugated double bonds in their aromatic rings.

Other options :

Option A: Leucine is an essential amino acid that is purely ketogenic. Elevated levels of leucine and isoleucine are seen in maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) due to decreased activity of the enzyme involved in the degradation of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine and valine)

Option B: Proline is an amino acid that plays a major role in collagen stability. It has an imino ring and is also hydrophobic in nature. Collagen is rich in proline and hydroxyproline.

Option C: Arginine is a semi-essential amino acid, it is in the production of nitric oxide, immune system support, wound healing, and harmone regulation.

questions.text:
In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following levels would be elevated after consuming a fatty meal?

LDL-Low density lipoprotein

HDL-High density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, chylomicron levels would be increased after eating a fatty meal.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols). Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Other options :

Option B:  Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is a fat that circulates in the blood, moving cholesterol around the body to where it is needed for cell repair and depositing it inside of artery walls. LDL receptor function is needed for the uptake of LDL from the blood into hepatocytes. Defects in LDL receptor function can cause hypercholesterolemia, known as familial hypercholesterolemia.

Option C: High-density lipoprotein (HDL) plays a crucial role in reverse cholesterol transport. It transports cholesterol from peripheral tissues to the liver. HDL carries LDL (bad) cholesterol away from the arteries and back to the liver, where the LDL is broken down and passed from the body.

Option D: Apolipoprotein A1 (Apo A1) activates lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT). LCAT is the enzyme present in HDL, which is activated by apo A1. LCAT converts free cholesterol (amphipathic) in HDL to cholesterol ester(hydrophobic). The initial discoidal shape now becomes spherical. This facilitates reverse cholesterol transport.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, TG and cholesterol Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following technique is used for detection of variation in DNA sequence and gene expression?
questions.solution:
The technique used for detection of variation in DNA sequence and gene expression is microarray technique.

Microarray technique can be used to study mutations in DNA and variations in gene expression. It consists of a slide with tiny spots of DNA called a DNA (or gene) chip. For studying gene expression, mRNA is taken from the sample and then its complementary DNA (cDNA) is made. This cDNA from the normal cell is labeled with green fluorescence, and the cDNA from the cancer cell is labeled with red fluorescence. Then, both are allowed to hybridize with the DNA on the chip.

Interpretation:

  • Black spots represent no expression by both normal and cancer cells.
  • Red spots represent more expression by the cancer cells.
  • Green spots represent more expression by normal cells.
  • Yellow spots represent equal expression by both cells.

Using the microarray technique, the differing patterns of gene expression between two types of cells can be analyzed.

The given image shows microarray slide.

Other options : 

Option B: Northern blotting only measures mRNA production from one gene at a time.

Option C: Southern blot can only analyze DNA not the products of DNA expression.

Option D: Southwestern blotting is used to detect protein-DNA interaction.

questions.text: The first heart sound coincides with which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
The first heart sound coincides with the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.

The time between the closure of the mitral valve and the opening of the aortic valve is the isovolumic contraction period. It begins with the closure of mitral and tricuspid valve which is responsible for the first heart sound. During this period, the ventricles contract as a closed chamber till the aortic and pulmonary valves open. 

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presented with seizures, loss of motor skills and increased startle response to noise. On fundoscopy, the following image was seen. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of seizures, loss of motor skills, increased startle response to noise, and a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy is suggestive of Tay-Sachs disease and the enzyme deficient is hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neurons. It can present during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot. Affected children usually die by the age of 10–15 years.

Note: Clinical features of Sandhoff's disease are similar to Tay-Sachs but additionally have hepatosplenomegaly and cardiac involvement. It is due to defective Hexosaminidase A and B.

Other options :

Option B:  A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows a crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy. 

Option C:  A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhoea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option D: Von Gierke’s disease occurs due to a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6 phosphatase. It is the most common of the glycogen storage diseases. Clinical manifestations result, directly or indirectly, from an inability to maintain an adequate blood glucose level, glycogen accumulation in organs, excessive lactic acid generation, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: All of the following are duties of a male health worker except?
questions.solution:
All of the options are duties of male health workers except maintenance of eligible couple registers.

The maintenance of eligible couple registers comes under the purview of the female health workers. She is also expected to regularly update it.

Male health workers are responsible for environmental sanitation. This includes chlorination of public water sources such as wells at regular intervals. They are expected to assist the accredited social health activist (ASHA) and other health volunteers in carrying out directly observed therapy, and short-course (DOTS) activities. He also motivates tuberculosis patients to adhere to regular treatment. They also have duties under the Reproductive and Child Health Program (RCH). This includes the distribution of conventional contraceptives to couples. He also helps prospective sterilization acceptors to undergo the procedure. 

Related Pearl: Responsibilities of Health Workers

Male Health Worker

  • Universal Immunization Program
  • Detection of non communicable diseases
  • Dai training
  • Treatment of minor ailments
  • Participate in team activities

  • National Health Programmes

  • Leprosy follow-up
  • Identification and follow-up cases of blindness
  • Reproductive and child health program (Educate about family planning and MTP, distrubute conventional contraceptives, follow up services to male family planning acceptors) 
  • RNTCP
  • Expanded Immunization Program
  • Environmental sanitation including chlorination of water and proper waste disposal

  • Distribution of contraceptives
  • Work on communicable diseases like DOTS activities

questions.text: Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein forms a major component of the organic matrix of renal casts.

Tamm-Horsfall protein, also known as uromodulin, is the most common protein present in urine and is produced in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. They are membrane-bound, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchored proteins that are released by proteolytic cleavage at the apical membrane. It is secreted as the most abundant protein in normal human urine (20 to 100 mg/day) and is not expressed by macula densa cells or the downstream distal convoluted tubule (DCT)

They form the major organic matrix of all renal casts and play a role in the modulation of innate immunity in the kidney and inflammation during kidney injury. Uromodulin is coded by the UMOD gene, and mutation of this can lead to medullary cystic kidney disease (MCKD II) and familial juvenile hyperuricemic nephropathy.

Casts are cylindrical structures that are formed in the DCT and collecting ducts. They assume the shape and size of the lumen in which they are formed. Several factors favor cast formation, such as urine stasis, low pH, and high concentration. All casts have an organic matrix composed primarily of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein. Casts are the only elements in urine sediments that are specific to renal origin.

Other options:

Option A: Thrombi occurring in heart chambers or the aortic lumen are designated mural thrombi. Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn, which are pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell–rich layers.

Option B: Curschmann spirals are a characteristic finding in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimens of patients with atopic asthma formed due to the extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles.

Option D: In multiple myeloma, the malignant plasma cells often secrete free, unpaired κ or λ light chains which are referred to as Bence-Jones proteins.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presenting with features of meningitis was further evaluated. CSF analysis shows normal glucose level, increased protein level, increased lymphocyte count, and increased opening pressure. Which of the following stains would help identify the organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the CSF findings and the given clinical scenario of an HIV-positive patient with features of meningitis, aetiology is likely to be of fungal origin. The organism is likely to be cryptococcus and the stain used for identifying it is an India ink stain.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly coloured background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes. The India ink preparation is widely employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream coloured, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

The image below shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with Indian ink.

Initiation with amphotericin B with flucytosine, which is followed by oral fluconazole as a maintenance treatment is the standard of care.

Other options.

Option A: Gram stain can identify Streptococcus pneumoniae or Neisseria meningitidis, which has elevated neutrophils, decreased glucose level, and increased protein level.

Option B: Gomori methenamine silver stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii which causes fungal pneumonia.

Option C: Acid-fast stain is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis which has lymphocyte predominance, decreased glucose, and elevated proteins.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except that :

choices.text: It is a purely motor nerve
It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except option A as it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with non-blanching rashes on the legs as seen in the image. He also complains of joint pain, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the urine.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 7-year-old boy with complaints of joint pain, abdominal pain, and vomiting, and the image showing palpable purpura are suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

Henoch schonlein purpura is also known as IgA vasculitis. It is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by palpable purpura, arthralgias, gastrointestinal signs and symptoms, and glomerulonephritis.

Gastrointestinal manifestations are colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, and passage of blood in stools.

It is more commonly seen in children aged 4-7 years. Some of the factors that trigger the development of HSP include upper respiratory infections, drugs, foods, insect bites, and immunizations.

Skin biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis by demonstrating the leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.

Henoch Schonlein purpura has an excellent prognosis. Patients with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis are treated with glucocorticoids.

Other options:

Option A: Bechet's syndrome is characterized by recurrent genital ulcers, oral ulcers, skin lesions, eye lesions, or a positive pathergy test. Some of the patients have HLA B51 positivity. Oral ulcers are usually the first manifestation of the disease.

Option C: Microscopic polyangiitis affects small and medium-sized arteries with a predilection to involve the capillaries and venules Glomerulonephritis and hemoptysis due to alveolar hemorrhage can also occur. 

Option D: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is a thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13 which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. It presents with the following pentad of clinical features:

  1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia - mechanical shearing of RBCs as they pass through platelet-rich-microthrombi
  2. Thrombocytopenia - deposition of platelets in microthrombi
  3. Renal failure - microthrombi in the renal vasculature
  4. Neurologic findings - headache, confusion, transient focal neurologic deficits
  5. Fever

questions.text: A neonatologist advises the family of a newborn weighing 1.9 kg to practice the following method. What is incorrect about the baby's positioning in this method?

choices.text: Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position.
The abdomen should be at the level of mother's epigastrium.
The legs should be extended and adducted.

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care (KMC), and the baby's legs must be flexed and abducted, not extended and adducted.

The Kangaroo positioning:

  • Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position. It keeps the airway of the baby open and allows eye-to-eye contact with the mother. 
  • The abdomen should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. The mother's breathing stimulates the baby, thus preventing apnea. 
  • The arms should be flexed.
  • The legs should be flexed and abducted in a 'Frog' position. 

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components:

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

KMC can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC can even be done on mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. 

The structure can be identified as the musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii. The root value of the musculocutaneous nerve is C5, C6, C7.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, which include coracobrachialis, brachialis, and biceps brachii muscles.

Other options:

Option B: The median nerve predominantly provides motor innervation to the flexor muscles of the forearm and hand as well as those muscles responsible for flexion, abduction, opposition, and extension of the thumb. The muscles are the thenar compartments of the palm, flexor pollicis longus, abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and adductor pollicis.

Option C: The ulnar nerve innervates the flexor muscles of the forearm including the flexor carpi ulnaris and flexor digitorum profundus. It also innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand including the palmaris brevis, lumbricals, hypothenar and interossei muscles.

Option D: Radial nerve innervates:

  • Triceps brachii (medial and lateral heads) — provides the extension of the forearm.
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus — provides for the extension of the wrist.
  • Brachioradialis — provides flexion of the elbow as well as pronation and supination, depending on the position of the forearm.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. This drug acts by inhibiting the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. Which of the following drugs is used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Warfarin acts by inhibiting the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase.

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

The half-life of proteins C and S are 8 and 24 hours, respectively, which is relatively shorter than the half-lives of other clotting factors, particularly factor II. Therefore, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin is not achieved for 4 to 5 days. For this reason, warfarin must be bridged with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, in patients with thrombosis or at high risk for thrombosis.

Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome (due to cholesterol microemboli released from atheromatous plaques, which cause arteriolar occlusion), and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

Warfarin is mainly metabolized by the CYP2C9 enzyme. Drugs that affect the CYP2C9 enzyme can alter the anticoagulant function of warfarin and these include the following:

Reduced efficacy:

  • CYP2C9 activation by drugs: barbiturates, carbamazepine, rifampin
  • Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors

Increased efficacy:

  • Drugs causing CYP2C9 inhibition:
    • Amiodarone
    • Azole antifungals
    • Cimetidine
    • Clopidogrel
    • Cotrimoxazole
    • Disulfiram
    • Isoniazid
    • Metronidazole

Other options:
 
Option B: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.
 
Option C: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of embolism and stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Bleeding and dyspepsia are the most important adverse effects.
 
Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct inhibitor of factor Xa. It is used for prophylaxis and treatment of deep vein thrombosis. Side effects reported are bleeding, nausea, hypotension, tachycardia, and edema.

questions.text: As a medical officer, you are asked to educate the students in your community about following a healthy lifestyle from a very young age. Also, lifestyle modifications and ill effects of alcohol and drugs are planned to be taught to the students. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Educating the students about following a healthy lifestyle and the ill effects of alcohol and drugs falls under the primordial level of prevention. 

The primordial level of prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.

Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken for this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Examples of the concerns addressed at this level include adult health problems, like obesity and hypertension, that have an early onset due to lifestyle factors, like smoking, poor eating patterns, and lack of physical exercise; preventive measures are directed at discouraging these practices from early childhood.

Other options:

Option A: Secondary prevention includes early disease detection and targets healthy-looking individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. Secondary prevention is defined as an intervention that halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Option C: Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and to minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Option D: Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a disease.

questions.text: A person develops headache and breathlessness on a trekking expedition following rapid ascent to over 3000 metres above the sea level. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of headache and breathlessness following rapid ascent indicate acute mountain/altitude sickness and IV digoxin is not used to treat this condition. 

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that increases the force of contraction of the heart (positive inotropic effect) and can also affect heart rate and rhythm. Hypoxia (due to reduced oxygen) already places additional stress on the heart, and the use of digoxin may worsen this stress by increasing the demand on the heart, particularly in conditions where the oxygen supply is already insufficient.

On ascent to high altitudes, the low partial pressure of oxygen leads to hypoxia and systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue, causing symptoms like headache, irritation, insomnia, breathlessness, nausea and vomiting.

Treatment involves administration of oxygen (Option C), descent to a lower altitude (Option B) and administration of acetazolamide (Option D). Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby girl presented with delayed eruption of teeth and a reddish discolouration as shown in the image below. She had a history of blisters over the face, hands and feet on exposure to sunlight since the 6th day of birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, along with the findings in the image, points towards a diagnosis of congenital erythropoietic porphyria.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, also known as Gunther's disease, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in uroporphyrinogen III synthase. It often presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. A hallmark of the condition is severe cutaneous photosensitivity. As a result of the defect, uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in various tissues, including the teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma, urine, and feces.

One of the characteristic signs is port-wine-colored urine, or a pink stain in diapers. When exposed to ultraviolet (UV) light, the teeth exhibit a reddish fluorescence known as erythrodontia.

Severe photosensitivity, red fluorescent urine, and erythrodontia are typically diagnostic features of congenital erythropoietic porphyria. In some cases, individuals with significant disfigurement and photosensitivity have been historically suggested as the inspiration for werewolf legends.

Other options :

Option B: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda is the most common form of porphyria, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. The hallmark feature of PCT is the development of blistering skin rashes that rupture and form crusts in sun-exposed areas, such as the hands, face, and upper body. Hypertrichosis, particularly on the face, is also a common finding.

Option C: Erythropoietic protoporphyria is caused by the deficiency of ferrochelatase and presents with cutaneous photosensitivity with skin lesions.

Option D: Acute intermittent porphyria is due to a defect in HMB synthase, usually inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. It presents with abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. There will be elevated aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic porphyria

Hepatic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency early in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of ALA and PBG. The patient principally presents with neurovisceral symptoms.

Erythropoietic porphyria is caused due to enzyme deficiency late in the pathway of heme synthesis. There is an accumulation of porphyrins which leads to cutaneous photosensitivity.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. HRCT chest was done which showed pleural thickening,  pleural plaques, and pleural fibrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the HRCT chest showing pleural thickening, plaques, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes and may present with dyspnoea and cough, usually after 20-30 years of exposure. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Workers in the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques are calcified resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray/ CT scan. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Histopathological findings: Asbestos bodies are a hallmark finding. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

The image below shows asbestos bodies.

Other options:

Option A: Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining. Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages. Shown below is an image of a silicotic nodule with collagen whorls as seen in this condition.

Option C: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis which is called complicated coal workers pneumoconiosis. The upper lobes of the lungs are commonly involved. Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis. 

The image below shows anthracosis- black pigment engulfed within macrophages in the form of deposits.

Option D: Cotton dust causes byssinosis and can induce occupational asthma.

questions.text: Arrange the cyclins in the correct sequence according to their roles in the cell cycle, starting from the G1 (Gap 1) phase and progressing to the G2 (Gap 2) phase.

choices.text: Cyclin B- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin D
Cyclin E- Cyclin B- Cyclin A-  Cyclin D
Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A-  Cyclin B
Cyclin B- Cyclin A- Cyclin E-  Cyclin D

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cyclins through the G1- S- G2 phase is  Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin B.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2.
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2.
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1.

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

The image below shows the different checkpoints and cell cycle regulators :

CDK: Cyclin-dependent kinase

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is

choices.text: It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.solution:
True statement regarding mitochondrial dna is It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA.

Mitochondrial DNA is circular, double-stranded DNA composed of heavy and light chains and comprises about 1% of total cellular DNA. It contains about 16,569 base pairs and encodes about 13 protein subunits of the electron transport chain, of a total of about 67 protein subunits.

Its genetic code/ nucleotide sequence largely differs from that of the standard cellular code. For example, the standard stop codon UGA is read as tryptophan (Trp); in addition, few untranslated sequences exist and a very high mutation rate, about 5-10 times compared to that of nuclear DNA of the cell is observed.

As all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during zygote formation, human mitochondrial DNA is transmitted by maternal non-mendelian inheritance. This is clinically significant because in diseases resulting from mutations of mitochondrial DNA, except in a few cases, an affected mother would pass the disease to all of her children but only her daughters would transmit the trait.

Other options : 

Option A:  Mitochondrial dna is not transmitted one set from each parents. It is transmitted by maternal non-mendelian inheritance.

Option C: Mitochondrial dna doesnot codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain of a total of about 67 protein subunits (i.e about 20%).

Option D: It has 16,569 bp (that makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA) while nuclear DNA has 3.3 billion bp. 

A Mutation in mitochondrial DNA results in MELAS(Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke) an inherited condition due to NADH-Q oxidoreductase (Complex I) or cytochrome oxidase (Complex IV) deficiency.

questions.text: Mitral leaflet calcification and fish mouth appearance of the mitral orifice are noted in the autopsy of a young woman. Also, small, warty vegetations on mitral valve leaflets and an enlarged left atrium are noted. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with mitral leaflet calcification, fish mouth appearance of the mitral orifice(luminal narrowing), small, warty vegetations on mitral valve leaflets and an enlarged left atrium are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). 

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to the narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

Image: Histology of a rheumatic fever patient showing Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells.

Other options:

Option B: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart or mural endocardium. The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly involved. The vegetation present on the valves are large, friable, bulky, destructive lesions that contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, and bacteria or other organisms.

Option C: Marantic endocarditis/Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by small, sterile thrombi on the leaflets of the cardiac valves. It is seen in patients with cancer or sepsis. 

Option D: Libman-Sacks endocarditis is seen in people with systemic lupus erythematosus. They have medium to small-sized vegetation appearing on both sides of the leaflets. They may occur on any site like the surface of the valve, chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium.

questions.text: Identify the papulosquamous disorder associated with the following clinical presentation:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is of Pityriasis rubra pilaris.

The given image shows erythematous follicular hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis and acanthosis in the epidermis seen in Pityriasis rubra pilaris. This is mainly seen over the elbows, knees, wrists and back of fingers.

  • Patient characteristically have a 'nutmeg grater' appearance in pityriasis rubra pilaris
  • Patients typically present with well‐defined salmon‐red or orange-red dry scaly plaques, which may coalesce and become widespread.
  • Typically islands of normal skin are present, the so‐called ‘islands of sparing’.
  • The disease often starts on the scalp before spreading down over the rest of the body.
  • Some patients may become erythrodermic.
  • Pruritus may be present in the early stages of the disease.

The given image shows Nutmeg grater.

Other options :

Option A:  Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. 

Option B: Lichen nitidus is a rare variant of lichen planus, where both are histologically similar in early lesions. It is mostly seen in children and young adults. Lesions of lichen nitidus are typically described as a minute pinpoint to pinhead-size, flat or dome-shaped papules with a shiny surface. They are most commonly found over the forearm, dorsum of the penis, abdomen, chest, and buttocks.

Option C: Follicular eczema is a form of atopic dermatitis that presents with a discoid patch formed due to the coalescence of the follicular lesions with peripheral excoriation marks. The biopsy shows spongiotic dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with the inability to form words but can make noises. However, he knows what he wants to say. Identify the area of the brain that has been damaged in this patient.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is Broca's area (areas 44 and 45), which is damaged in this patient.

Broca's area is the motor speech area located in the inferior frontal gyrus. The patient knows what he wants to say, indicating that the comprehension of speech is intact. He is unable to form words due to an impairment in the fluency of speech. This patient is suffering from Broca's aphasia due to the said damage.
