questions.text:
A 40-year-old man was admitted with a large wound on his leg for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. He was given linezolid. What is the mechanism of action of the above drug?

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus

choices.text: Binds to 30s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Binds to 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Disrupts the structure of cell membrane

questions.solution:
The drug linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various gram-positive organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, and vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. 

Staphylococci become resistant by acquiring penicillin-binding protein (PBP) to become methicillin-resistant staphylococci. 

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA-approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse effects include:

  • Myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • Thrombocytopenia (most common side effect)
  • Serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • Peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Other options:

Option A - Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. These bactericidal agents are mainly used to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

 Option C- Polymyxins act by interacting with the phospholipids and disrupting the structure of the cell membrane. It can be used systemically for bacteremia, pneumonia, bone/joint infections, burns, cellulitis, cystic fibrosis, endocarditis, gynecologic infections, meningitis, and ventriculitis. Polymyxin B is used topically for corneal ulcers, and eye and skin infections. Side effects include dose-related nephrotoxicity, muscle weakness, vertigo, and slurring of speech.

Option D - Glycopeptides inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine and the class originator drug is vancomycin. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, meningitis, and staphylococcal endocarditis. Redman syndrome (erythema, flushing, tachycardia, and hypotension), ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

questions.text: A patient in the emergency room with a road traffic accident has signs of hypotension. Bleeding  from a retroperitoneal organ is  suspected. Trauma to which of the following structures is the most likely the cause of a  retroperitoneal bleed?
questions.solution:
The pancreas is the most likely cause as it is a retroperitoneal structure. All the other structures listed are intraperitoneal.

Relationship of viscera to the peritoneum:

  • Intraperitoneal: Stomach, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, transverse colon, sigmoid colon, liver, gall bladder, and spleen.
  • Retroperitoneal: Esophagus (abdominal), duodenum (2nd and 3rd segment), pancreas, kidneys, ureters, suprarenal glands, abdominal aorta and its branches, inferior vena cava, and celiac plexus.
  • Partially covered in the peritoneum (also considered as retroperitoneal): Ascending colon, descending colon, and rectum.

Note: A useful mnemonic to remember which organs are retroperitoneal is: SAD PUCKER

S: suprarenal (adrenal) gland
A: aorta/IVC
D: duodenum (second, third and fourth parts)
P: pancreas (except tail)
U: ureters
C: colon (ascending and descending)
K: kidneys
E: (o)oesophagus
R: rectum

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding smooth muscle is false?

choices.text: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential
Dense bodies are present instead of Z lines
It can exert a variable tension at any given length
Sympathetic stimulation produces excitatory membrane potentials

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding smooth muscle is sympathetic stimulation produces excitatory membrane potentials.

Sympathetic stimulation (norepinephrine) of a smooth muscle produces inhibitory potentials and relaxation and parasympathetic stimulation (acetylcholine) causes depolarization and contraction.

Smooth muscle can be divided into:

  • Unitary smooth muscle - has low-resistance gap junctions between individual muscle cells and functions in a syncytial manner.
  • Multiunit smooth muscle -  made up of individual units with few or nil gap junctions.

Blood vessels have both unitary and multiunit smooth muscle in their walls.

Other options:

Option A: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential with continuous irregular contractions independent of its nerve supply. This state of partial contraction is called tonus or tone.

Option B: Dense bodies are present instead of Z lines in smooth muscle. These are bound to actin filaments by α-actinin.

Option C: Smooth muscle can exert variable tension at any given length. This property is called plasticity. When a unitary smooth muscle is stretched, it first exerts increased tension. However, if it is held at this length after stretching, the tension gradually decreases.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman was found to have excessive urinary glucose levels. However, her blood glucose levels were normal. Further investigations revealed high levels of L-xylulose in the urine. A genetic defect in which of the following pathways is most likely responsible for this condition?

TCA cycle-tricarboxylic acid cycle

HMP-Hexosemophosphate shunt
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario the genetic defect is in the uronic acid pathway.

High levels of L-xylulose in urine are diagnostic of essential pentosuria, a benign condition caused due to a defect in the uronic acid pathway. Essential pentosuria has no clinical consequences. However, it can give false-positive results when urinary glucose is measured using alkaline copper reagents (Benedict’s test).

Essential pentosuria is due to the lack of enzyme xylulose reductase of the uronic acid pathway. Affected individuals excrete large amounts of L-xylulose in urine. Xylulose being a reducing sugar gives Benedict's test positive. Bial's test is positive as xylulose is a pentose. It is a part of Garrod's tetrad which includes, pentosuria, albinism, cystinuria and alkaptonuria.

Other options :

Option A: The tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle), also called the citric acid cycle or the Krebs cycle is the final pathway where the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids occurs with their carbon skeletons being converted to carbon dioxide (CO2). This oxidation provides energy for the production of the majority of ATP. 

Option C: Glycolysis is the main pathway through which cells metabolize glucose and other carbohydrates. It occurs in the cytosol of cells and can function either aerobically or anaerobically depending on the availability of oxygen and the activity of the electron transport chain (and hence of the presence of mitochondria). Erythrocytes, which lack mitochondria, are completely reliant on glucose as their metabolic fuel and metabolize it by anaerobic glycolysis. 

Option D: The pentose phosphate pathway or HMP shunt is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It does not lead to the formation of ATP, but it has two major functions of, formation of NADPH and synthesis of ribose-5-phosphate.

Related Pearl: Essential Pentosuria

questions.text: Which of the following statements about disaster management is incorrect?

choices.text: Rehabilitation is the final phase in a disaster that leads to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions.
Disaster mitigation is a risk reduction measure before the occurrence of a disaster.
Disaster preparedness is short-term developmental activity.
The response includes triage, tagging, identification of the dead, and relief activities.

questions.solution:
Disaster preparedness refers to long-term development activities to strengthen the capacity of a country to effectively manage all kinds of emergencies. 

Response - This includes activities such as:

Triage: Classifying the injured based on the severity of the injuries and chances of survival with medical intervention. 

Tagging: Tags with name, age, triage category, diagnosis, and treatment are put for identification purposes. 

Identification of the dead: The dead bodies should be shifted from the disaster site to the mortuary.

  • Rehabilitation - This includes measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.
  • Mitigation - This includes measures to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of them are flood mitigation, land use planning, improved building codes, and the reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures. 
  • Preparedness - This is a program that aims at strengthening the capacity of a country to manage all types of emergencies efficiently. Its objective is to ensure that appropriate measurements are taken for the relief and rehabilitation of disaster victims.

Some measures that should be followed by all in case of an emergency include:

  • Avoiding telephone use, unless it is to call for help
  • Listen to and carry out the radio or loudspeaker broadcast messages
  • Carry out the official instructions given over the radio or by loudspeaker
  • Keep a family emergency kit ready

Note: Vaccination of the general population post-disaster against typhoid, cholera, and tetanus is not recommended by World Health Organization(WHO).

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care in a community.

Infant mortality rate (IMR) = Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births x 1000.

It is one of the universally accepted healthcare indicators for the whole population and the socioeconomic conditions under which they live.

Other options:

Option B:  While the maternal mortality rate is an important indicator of maternal healthcare services, it is not as sensitive as the infant mortality rate in reflecting the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community.

Option C: Immunization coverage is an essential factor in preventing diseases and promoting public health. However, it is a narrower indicator than the infant mortality rate, focusing primarily on preventive healthcare services for children. Full immunization coverage is defined as the proportion of infants 9-11 months old who have received the 3 doses of DPT vaccine, BCG vaccine, 3 doses of OPV, and one dose of measles vaccine against the estimated number of infants during a specific year.

Option D: Disability-adjusted life years are a useful measure of the overall burden of disease in a population, but they are less sensitive in assessing the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare services in a community compared to the infant mortality rate.

questions.text: A man who is a chronic alcoholic has abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and mucosal ulcers. A stool examination revealed the following. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with stool examination showing a large ovoid trophozoite with cilia all over the surface suggests balantidiasis, the causative organism for which is Balantidium coli. 

It is the only ciliated protozoan and is present as a commensal in the large intestine. It is mostly asymptomatic in healthy individuals. However, certain predisposing factors such as malnourishment, alcoholism, concurrent infection with Trichuris trichiura, or bacterial infection can cause clinical infection.

Clinical manifestations include mucosal ulcers, diarrhea, frank dysentery, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. 

Diagnosis is by stool examination, showing the presence of trophozoites in diarrheic feces and cysts in formed stools. Trophozoites are large in size, with a macronucleus and rapid-revolving motility, while cysts are round with a macronucleus.

The trophozoite is shown in the image below:

Treatment is with tetracycline 500 mg 4 times a day for 10 days. 

Other options:

Option A: Babesia infection causes babesiosis, which is a disease that resembles malaria. Diagnosis is by the examination of blood smears stained with Leishman or Giemsa stain, where Babesia appears as intraerythrocytic round, pyriform, or ring forms, like Plasmodium falciparum.

Option B: Cyclospora infection causes prolonged diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting which is more severe in immunocompromised individuals. On wet mount, oocysts are seen as red spheres when stained with acid-fast stain.

Option D: Isospora belli infection causes watery diarrhea that is self-limiting. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

questions.text: A pedestrian is hit by a car, hurled up on the windshield, following which his head strikes the road. The latter is an example of?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is an example of tertiary impact injury.

In this case, impact with the road is an example of tertiary impact injuries as the pedestrian sustained impacts twice (car bumper and windshield) before hitting on the road. 

Injuries to pedestrians are of 3 types :

  • Primary impact injuries are caused by the first impact of the vehicle on the victim.
  • Secondary impact injuries are further injuries caused by the vehicle.
  • Tertiary injuries are caused when the victim strikes other objects or falls on the ground after being hit by the vehicle.

Note: In case a pedestrian is hit by the vehicle only once(i.e only primary impact and no secondary impact by the vehicle) and then sustains injuries by falling on the road, it would be an example of secondary injuries.

Other options : 

Option A: Primary impact injury is caused by the first impact of the vehicle on the victim.

Option B: Secondary impact injury is a further injury caused by the vehicle.

Option D: Quarternary impact injury is not classified.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abnormal skin pigmentation over his forearms and face. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Which stain has been used to identify his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features suggest a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Prussian blue stain is used to identify this condition. On this stain, the hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes appear blue in color. 

Hemochromatosis occurs due to excessive iron absorption that leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs. It involves liver, pancreas, myocardium,endocrine organs (pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands), joints and skin.

It can be primary hemochromatosis (inherited disorder) or secondary hemochromatosis (accumulation of iron due to other causes). The adult form of primary hemochromatosis usually occurs due to mutations of the HFE gene.

Clinical features include:

  • Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly
  • Diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of pancreatic islets
  • Slate-grey color skin pigmentation due to increased melanin production
  • Cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy)
  • Acute synovitis due to excessive deposition of calcium pyrophosphate that produces disabling polyarthritis known as pseudogout
  • Atrophic testes secondary to pituitary involvement

The image below shows a slide of liver microscopy that has been stained with Perls Prussian blue stain. The hepatocellular iron appears blue due to the stain.

Other options:

Option A: Masson trichrome stain can be used to demonstrate collagen. 

Option B: Congo red stain can be used to demonstrate the accumulation of amyloid.

Option C: Sudan black stain is a fat-soluble dye that is used to demonstrate lipid inclusions.

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is glycine.

Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of negative feedback inhibition. The axon of a spinal motor neuron gives a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. This inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

The Renshaw cell releases glycine to reduce the activity of the motor neuron.

questions.text: A truck driver comes with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following investigations can be used to diagnose the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy which can be used in a low economic, low resource setting. 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

  • Treponemes generally are short and slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

The image given below shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy.

Other options:

Option B: HSV 2 antibody is used in the diagnosis of herpes genitalis. It is an infection of the genital skin or mucosa caused by  HSV 2 predominantly. It presents as painful genital ulcers and dysuria. It is usually preceded by a prodrome of general malaise.

Option C: The granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria take up bluish purple color when stained with Albert's stain. Albert’s stain, Neisser’s, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Option D: Acid-fast stain is used in the Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for the identification of acid-fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with hair loss at your clinic and reports having had typhoid fever 3 months ago. What is your clinical diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of telogen effluvium.

Telogen effluvium describes an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.

  • Acute telogen effluvium is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden starvation or haemorrhage.
  • Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting for longer than 6 months. Causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are thyroid disorders, profound iron deficiency anaemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition. Both hyper and hypo­thyroidism (including drug-induced hypothyroidism) may cause a diffuse telogen hair loss.
  • Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth.

The image below shows telogen effluvium.

Other options :

Option A : Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease causing non-scarring hair loss. It is characterized by a circumscribed, smooth patch of hair loss. Exclamation mark hairs are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease. 

The image below shows aloplecia areata.

Option B :  Androgenetic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fibre production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types, male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex. Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. 

The image with finding of androgenic aloplecia is given below.

 

Option D : Alopecia after chemotherapy is known as anagen effluvium. The hair loss is generally acute and diffuse. Hair shedding generally starts within 1–3 weeks and is completed within 1–2 months of initiation of chemotherapy.

The image findings of anagen effluvium is given below.

questions.text: A young man was started on the drug which is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of platelets after percutaneous coronary intervention. Identify this drug.
questions.solution:
Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of the platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients. 

Side effects include bleeding and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura in rare cases. Administration of prasugrel with an anticoagulant or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug is avoided as it may increase the risk of bleeding. Contraindicated in patients above 75 years of age and those with a history of cerebrovascular disease.

Other options:

Option A: Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Tirofiban acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. It has a short duration of action and is used for the management of patients with non–non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome.

Option C: Eptifibatide acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions gives the haematological picture as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given haematological picture showing basophilic stippling with Cabot's ring is suggestive of chronic lead poisoning also called as plumbism or saturnism.

Clinical features of lead poisoning include

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling.
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums).
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain).
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy.
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma).
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign.

Other Options:

Option A : Minamata disease is chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.

Option C : Chronic iron toxicity, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).

Option D : Arsenic poisoning can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing the cadaveric specimen of the inferior surface of the liver. Which of the following lobe is referred to as segment I?
questions.solution:
The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe which is referred to as segment I.

Couinaud's segmental division of the liver is the functional division based on the portal venous branches in the parenchyma. They are divided into 8 functional segments. The caudate lobe corresponds to segment I of Couinaud's segments.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver and also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. 

The caudate lobe is visible as prominent on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

Other markings:

1-Quadrate lobe

2-Right lobe

4-Left Lobe

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's Liver Segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of infection involving skin and hair, sparing the nails and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

questions.text: Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are  stimulated by all except____
questions.solution:
Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by acidic contents, not alkaline.

The duodenal factors that can initiate enterogastric inhibitory reflexes (enterogastric reflexes) are:

  • Distention of the duodenum. (Option C)
  • The presence of any irritation of the duodenal mucosa. (Option D)
  • The acidity of the duodenal chyme.
  • The osmolality of the chyme (OptionB) - either hypotonic or hypertonic fluid initiates enterogastric inhibitory reflexes. Thus, the flow of non-isotonic fluids into the small intestine is regulated. This prevents rapid changes in electrolyte concentrations in the extracellular fluid during the absorption of the intestinal contents.
  • The presence of certain breakdown products in the chyme, especially proteins and to a lesser extent, of fats.

questions.text: Which of the following citric acid cycle intermediate is a part of heme metabolism?
questions.solution:
Succinyl CoA, a citric acid cycle intermediate, is also involved in heme metabolism. 
The synthesis of heme begins by condensation of succinyl Co-A and glycine to form α-amino-β-ketoadipate, which is then converted to δ-aminolevulinate. These steps are mediated by the enzyme ALA synthase. This step requires pyridoxal phosphate as co enzyme.

Various steps involved in the synthesis of heme are illustrated below.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought with complaints of multiple hyperpigmented papules over the face and other sun-exposed areas with persistent erythema. He has a history of similar episodes since childhood. Which mechanism is most likely defective in this condition?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched base during DNA replication
Removal of oligonucleotides containing damaged bases by endonuclease
Removal of the altered base by base specific glycosylase

questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum and the defect associated is the removal of oligonucleotides containing damaged bases by endonuclease (defective nucleotide excision repair).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.  

Clinical features include intense cutaneous photosensitivity, xerosis, poikiloderma, actinic keratosis, acute burning under minimal sun exposure, erythemas, hyperpigmented lentiginous macules, and malignant lesions in sun-exposed areas, including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma. The final diagnosis of XP can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to ultraviolet radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy and culture of skin fibroblasts.  

There is no cure for XP. Treatment consists of minimizing exposure to sunlight and regular dermatological care, as well as surgery for recurrent tumors excision. Patients should be followed up every 3 months. Genetic counseling is important in a family that has an affected child and is considering having more children.

Other options :

Option A: Removal of mismatched bases during DNA replication is mismatch repair (MMR). It is a DNA repair pathway that repairs errors that occur during DNA replication. Defects in MMR can cause Lynch syndrome.

Option C: Removal of the altered base by base-specific glycosylase is called base excision repair. A base excision repair defect is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis syndrome.

Option D: Double-strand breaks are caused by ionizing radiation and are corrected by nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ).

questions.text: An 8-month-old male infant is found to have bilateral renal masses. The infant had an omphalocele, macroglossia and macrosomia at birth. Which of the following is the genetic basis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with bilateral renal masses, and history of omphalocele, macroglossia, and macrosomia at birth most likely has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which occurs due to genomic imprinting.

Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome is characterized by neonatal hypoglycemia, macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia. omphalocele, visceromegaly and embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is the WT2 locus in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) distal to the WT1 locus. This region contains multiple genes that are normally expressed from only one of the two parental alleles, with silencing (imprinting) of the other. IGF2 gene abnormalities have the strongest correlation to the development of tumors. Loss of maternal imprinting of IGF2 and uniparental paternal disomy of IGF2 are 2 pathways that can cause overexpression of IGF2 thus leading to tumorigenesis.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Other options: 

Option A: Mosaicism is the phenomenon where a single organism possesses more than one genetic line as the result of genetic mutation.

Option B: Anticipation is the phenomenon where symptoms become more severe and/or appear at an earlier age as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next.

Option D: De novo mutation such as germline deletions of 11p13 is associated with WAGR syndrome. In Denys-Drash syndrome the genetic abnormality is a dominant-negative missense mutation in the zinc-finger region of the WT1 protein that affects its DNA-binding properties.

questions.text: Which of the following has the lowest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Among the fetal blood vessels mentioned above, the superior vena cava (SVC) has the lowest oxygen concentration. It carries deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium.

The pO2 of SVC is about 12-14 mmHg whereas the pO2 of the umbilical artery is about 20-25 mm Hg. This is because the SVC carries only deoxygenated blood, whereas the umbilical artery carries a mix of oxygenated blood from the ascending aorta and deoxygenated blood from systemic circulation.

Fetal circulation:

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities, carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. 

The blood then enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives purely deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This blood then enters the pulmonary artery. Since fetal lungs are collapsed, most of the blood enters the descending aorta via ductus arteriosus and is then distributed to the body. 

Finally, some of this blood from the aorta and the lower parts of the body is pumped back to the placenta via umbilical arteries. Hence, they contain a mix of both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. 

The rough estimate of oxygenation of the vessels in the fetal circulation is given below:

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min.

questions.text: Which of the following genes is involved in Cowden syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome occurs due to the mutation of the PTEN gene.

Phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN)-10q23 is a tumor suppressor gene and it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Cowden syndrome is characterized by skin appendage tumors and an increased incidence of epithelial cancers, particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid.

Other options:

Option A- CDKN2A- Involved in familial melanoma and sporadic carcinomas of the pancreas, breast, and esophagus.

Option B- VHL- Codes for von Hippel–Lindau protein and is involved in von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (cerebellar hemangioblastoma, retinal angioma, renal cell carcinoma)

Option C- PTCH- Involved in Gorlin syndrome (basal cell carcinoma, medulloblastoma, several benign tumors)

questions.text: The given condition is most prominent after how many hours of death:
questions.solution:
The given condition is of postmortem marbling and it becomes prominet in 36-48 hours.

In postmortem marbling, blood in the vessels is haemolysed to sulfmethhemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins by about 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36–48 hours after death. The image below shows postmortem marbling which is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

Other options :

Option A : Postmortem marbling starts within 24 hours after death.

Option B : Postmortem marbling becomes more pronounced between 36 to 48 hours, but not within 24 to 36 hours.

Option D : Postmortem marbling does not become prominent within 48 to 60 hours.

questions.text: Identify the hormone demonstrating the depicted fluctuations:
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and the early period of sleep(Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep(REM Sleep).

Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m(REM Sleep).

questions.text: A patient is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Identify the correct pair of the serological test and culture media from the following.

choices.text: Elek Gel precipitation test - Potassium tellurite agar

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine is suggestive of infection with Leptospirosis(Weil's disease). The microscopic agglutination test is the serological test used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used for leptospira. 

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by leptospira. Humans are infected when the leptospires in water contaminated by the urine of carrier animals enter the body through cuts or abrasions on the skin or through the intact mucosa of the mouth, nose, or conjunctiva.

Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache, and intense injection of the eyes. Some may present as aseptic meningitis or with hepatorenal damage (Weil's disease).

Diagnosis includes:

Microscopy:

  • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from the blood after 1 week.
  • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposits of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.

Culture: With semisynthetic media like EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.

Serotype-specific tests:

  • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
  • Macroscopic agglutination test  
  • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Other options:

Option B: Elek Gel precipitation test - Potassium tellurite agar is for Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Option C: Ascoli's thermoprecipitation test - PLET medium is for Bacillus anthracis.

Option D: Cold agglutination test – Eaton’s agar is for Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

questions.text: In a modern sewage treatment plant, a light green oxidized flocculent material is formed after secondary treatment with the trickling filter method. This material is called____.
questions.solution:
The light green oxidized sewage formed after secondary treatment (trickling filter method) is called humus. It is then led toward the secondary sedimentation.

Other options:

Option B: Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of the primary treatment of sewage.

Option C: The effluent, formed from the primary sedimentation tank, contains a proportion of organic matter in solution or colloidal state and numerous living organisms.

Option D: Sullage is the waste water that doesn't contain human excreta.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She had sustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis.

About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or mammographic densities or calcifications.

Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification.

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue.

Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions -

  • Apo­crine cysts
  • Hyalinized fibroadenomas
  • Sclerosing adenosis
  • Duct ectasia 
  • Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcifications (microcalcifications).

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following structures would most likely be affected?
questions.solution:
A tumor in the deep perineal space is most likely to affect the bulbourethral glands as they are present in the deep perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, and superficial transverse perineal
  • The Bartholin’s glands (greater vestibular glands) in females and the duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (posterior scrotal and transverse perineal arteries) and branches of artery of the penis (artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis, and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, branches of the perineal nerve (posterior scrotal, nerve to bulb and muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: A new complement inhibitor, CI-100, is being investigated for safety and efficacy in 300 patients with active vasculitis. The trial randomizes patients to receive either CI-100 or placebo. What phase is this trial currently in?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes a randomized study to assess the safety and efficacy of the drug in 300 patients, which was conducted during phase 2 of the trial.

Phase 2 trials are designed to assess the efficacy and safety of a new drug in a larger group of patients (50 - 500). The primary goal of a phase 2 trial is to determine whether the new drug is effective in treating the target disease or condition.

Clinical trials are experimental studies involving humans that compare the therapeutic benefits of 2 or more treatment options, or of a particular treatment to a placebo. 

Other options:

Option A: Phase 1 where subjects (mostly about 10-100 healthy volunteers) are exposed to the lowest possible dose, increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose. The emphasis is to work out the safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous side effects.

Option C: Phase 3 involves a large number of patients (about 500-3000) being assigned randomly to either the treatment under investigation (e.g., drug CI-100 in the question) or to the present standard of care (e.g., steroids as the first-line treatment of vasculitis). The aim is to establish the value of the drug in relation to existing therapy. If it is better than existing modalities, indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated.

Option D: Phase 4 involves postmarketing surveillance of patients after the treatment is approved. It is used to detect efficacy, rare or long-term adverse effects, and evaluate cost-effectiveness.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with severe itching and skin lesions, showing multiple red and yellow crusts. Examination reveals a negative Nikolsky's sign. Immunofluorescence microscopy shows a subepidermal split and IgG deposition at the dermo-epidermal junction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts bullous pemphigoid. 

Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal immunobullous disorder. It occurs due to the production of autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP230(BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes.

The patients are usually elderly and present with itching and tense bullae, mainly on the flexural areas and the abdomen. These blisters might rupture and give rise to hemorrhagic or yellow crusts. Mucosal membrane involvement is rare in this disease. Most of the lesions heal without a scar. Since these bullae are subepidermal, pressure over the lesions does not separate the epidermis from the dermis (Nikolsky sign is negative).

Immunofluorescent microscopy will show the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction. Histopathology will show the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils.

It is mainly treated with corticosteroids. Other drugs used are azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, etc.

The below image shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in bullous pemphigoid.

Other options:

Option A- Pemphigus vulgaris is an intraepidermal immunobullous disease. It occurs commonly between the 4th to 6th decade. These present with flaccid blisters. Firm pressure over the lesion separates the epidermis from the dermis. Nikolsky's sign is positive. Mucosal involvement will be seen in the form of buccal and palatal erosions.

The immunofluorescence image showing fish net pattern is shown in the image below.

Option C- Dermatitis herpetiformis typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. The majority of the patients have symptoms related to gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea, and other gastrointestinal complaints. Immunofluorescence microscopy will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. 

Image showing focal granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae, typically seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

Option D- Impetigo herpetiformis is a type of generalized pustular psoriasis (GPP) occurring in pregnancy. It presents with flexural erythema, pustules, and periumbilical pustulation, and can be associated with fever, tetany, and hypocalcemia.

The image below shows impetigo herpetiformis.

questions.text: In which stage of sleep are K-complexes and sleep spindles seen?

questions.text: A neonate was diagnosed with meningitis. The organism showed resistance to bacitracin. What is the most likely cause for this neonate's condition?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows β-hemolysis on blood agar, is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test.

S. agalactiae is a capsulated Gram-positive coccus occurring in chains. It causes meningitis in the neonatal period. Infection is commonly acquired from the maternal vagina during birth. There are two clinical types seen in neonates:
  • Early-onset type (more common) presents within a week of birth as meningitis or septicemia and is often fatal.
  • Late-onset type presents between the second to twelfth week of life commonly as septicemia.

The CAMP test (Christie, Atkins and Munch-Peterson) is used to identify group B β-hemolytic-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor. This factor causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus, when Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a streak of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar. This produces the characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis.

The image given below shows a positive CAMP test.

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics which differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

Species Lancefield Group Typical Hemolysis Important Lab Characteristics
S. pyogenes A β Bacitracin sensitive, PYR test positive
S. agalactiae B β Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

The illustration given below shows the classification of Streptococci.

The classification of gram-positive organisms is summarized in the flow chart below.

questions.text: A drug with a half-life of 8 hours is administered orally three times a day. How long will it take for the plasma concentration to reach a steady state?
questions.solution:
The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 8 hours, it will take 32-40 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 36 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with a longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where the dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

A graph is plotted between plasma drug concentration and time as shown below. The given graph depicts the plateau principle of drug accumulation on repeated oral dosing.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the outpatient department with fever and rash as shown below for the past 2 days. The rash was pleomorphic and first appeared on the trunk.  What is the secondary attack rate of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a pleomorphic rash are suggestive of chickenpox or varicella infection. The secondary attack rate of varicella infection is 70-90%. 

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of susceptible close contacts). The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. 

Varicella or chickenpox is a highly infectious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The mode of transmission from person to person is by droplet infection or by droplet nuclei. This virus can cross the placental barrier and cause congenital varicella.

The incubation period is usually 14 -16 days. The clinical course can be divided into 2 stages. The pre-eruptive stage is marked by the sudden onset of mild to moderate fever, back pain, shivering, and malaise. The eruptive stage is characterized by a rash that appears on the day of fever. They first appear on the trunk and then on the face, arms, and legs. It advances quickly through all stages of macule, papule, vesicle, and scab. Rash exhibits a characteristic feature called pleomorphism because all the above stages of rash may be seen simultaneously at one time. 

Most cases of chickenpox are mild and self-limiting. In children, acyclovir decreases symptoms if taken within 24 hours of the start of the rash, but it has no effect on complication rates, and it is not recommended for individuals with normal immune function.

questions.text: A father brings his child with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. He has been on a diet consisting mainly of rice water, after being exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months. Laboratory investigations show markedly low serum albumin levels. Which of the following clinical features is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with a distended abdomen, poor feeding and exclusively breastfed till the age of 8 months points to the diagnosis of Kwashiorkor. Flaky paint dermatosis is seen in this condition.

The skin abnormalities include increased pigmentation, shedding of skin cells, and dyspigmentation. The pigmentation may appear as overlapping patches resembling peeling paint.

Skin changes typically occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled peeling patches with pale skin underneath that are easily infected, known as flaky paint dermatosis.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema. The edema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs. It quickly develops into generalized edema affecting also the hands, arms, and face (moon face). 

The hair is sparse and easily pulled out and may lose its curl. In dark-haired children, the hair may turn pale or reddish, with alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand, known as flag sign. Children with edema are apathetic and often refuse to eat.

Other options: Simian facies, loose wrinkled skin, baggy pant appearance, and alert child with no edema are characteristic features of marasmus.

Given below is the image of a marasmic patient with its characteristic appearance

questions.text: You are a medical officer evaluating the community health meal programs in your area. One of the program's objectives is to attract more children to maintain attendance in school. Which one of the following statements about this meal program is correct?

choices.text: Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
Provides 1/2 of daily energy requirement and 1/3rd of daily protein requirement
Provides 1/4th of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/4th of daily protein requirement

questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the mid-day meal program is the meal should provide at least 1/3rd of the daily energy requirement and 1/2 of the daily protein requirement. 

The mid-day meal program (MDMP)/ school lunch program is catered to provide meals for school children. It is offered to school children in an effort to persuade more children to enroll in schools thereby improving children's literacy. It aims to maintain attendance in schools. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the minimum needs program. It is run by the Ministry of Education.

The meal provided under the MDMP should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets. It must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement for children in schools. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meals should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used whenever possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

The mid-day meal scheme functions under the ministry of Human Resources Development as a centrally sponsored scheme. Under this, a cooked mid-day meal with at least 300 calories and 8-12 grams of protein is provided to all children of classes I-V.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old pregnant woman has completed her 1st antenatal visit under the maternal and child health program (MCH). Now she is 14 weeks pregnant. How many more antenatal visits does she need to complete to fulfill the minimum requirement for antenatal visits under the MCH?

MCH- Maternal and Child Health
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, of a lady who has completed her 1st antenatal visit, should complete 3 more visits to fulfill the minimum requirement of 4 antenatal visits under MCH.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

It is advised that the woman should visit the medical officer at the PHC for an antenatal check-up during 3rd visit.

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO (not MCH), is 8.

The ideal number of antenatal visits a mother should take to the antenatal clinic is:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the next month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding services provided for high-risk groups under the targeted interventions of NACO?

NACO- National AIDS Control Organization
ICTC- Integrated Counseling and Testing Centers

choices.text: Screening and treatment of sexually transmitted infections

questions.solution:
Alcohol substitution therapy is not a service offered through targeted interventions for the high-risk group under NACO guidelines. 

The following are the main services offered through targeted interventions:

  • Detection and treatment of sexually transmitted infections
  • Condom distribution 
  • Condom promotion through social marketing 
  • Behavioral change communication
  • Creating an enabling environment with community involvement and participation
  • Linkages to integrated counseling and testing centers
  • Linkages with care and support services for HIV-positive high-risk groups.
  • Community organization and ownership building.
  • Specific interventions for injecting drug users 
    • Distribution of clean needles and syringes
    • Abscess prevention and management
    • Opioid substitution therapy
    • Linkage with detoxification/rehabilitation services.
  • Specific interventions for men who have sex with men/ transgenders:
    • Provision of lubricants
    • Specific interventions for transgenders/hijra populations
    • Provision of project-based STI clinics

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, who had been consuming maize as a primary staple food for an extended period, presented with glossitis and a pigmented rash in areas exposed to the sun. Additionally, a lesion was observed on his neck, as depicted in the image provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical secnario and image finding showing casal's necklace is suggestive of pellagra. It is caused due to niacin deficiency.

Niacin is a nutrient that is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. The term niacin represents two compounds nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. It acts as a precursor for the coenzymes NAD and NADP, which are important in various oxidation and reduction reactions.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra. It is usually seen in individuals with a corn/ maize-based staple diet, a history of alcohol consumption, hartnup disease, and carcinoid syndrome. 

The primary manifestations of pellagra are often referred to as the 4D's as follows, diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, leading to death. Other manifestations include, abdominal pain, loss of appetite, bright red glossitis, generalized weakness, irritability, casal’s necklace(pigmented scaly skin rash around the neck).

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone. Treatment is oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

Other options :

Option B : Scurvy is caused due to vitamin c deficiency. It is associated with symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and fatigue. Scurvy is not associated with a rash like the one described, nor does it typically cause cognitive dysfunction or diarrhea. Hence, high-dose vitamin C would not improve this patient’s symptoms.

Option C : Megaloblastic anemia is an RBC disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B12 or folic acid. This deficiency results in impaired DNA synthesis, leading to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Option D : Beri beri is caused due to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. It is characterized by symptoms such as muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular issues, and confusion.

questions.text: Identify the strict anaerobe among the following.
questions.solution:
The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

Prevotella species are gram-negative rods or coccobacilli. The most commonly isolated Prevotella species are P melaninogenica, Prevotella bivia, and Prevotella disiens. P melaninogenica is associated with upper respiratory tract infections. P bivia and P disiens occur in the female genital tract. Prevotella species are also found in brain and lung abscesses, empyema, pelvic inflammatory disease and tubo-ovarian abscesses.

Other options

Option A: Burkholderia cepacia belongs to the pseudomonad group and is gram-negative, aerobic rods.

Option B: Yersinia enterocolitica are gram-negative facultative anaerobes.

Option C: Stenotrophomonas maltophilia also belong to the pseudomonad group and are gram-negative, aerobic rods.

questions.text: In the graph below, which ions do A and B represent in terms of their permeability during action potential generation?

choices.text: A is Na+,  B is K+
A is Na+,  B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.solution:
In the given graph, showing action potential generation in terms of ion permeability, wave A represents Na+ and B represents K+. 

The sequence of events during the action potential occurs in 7 steps as described below.

1. Resting-state - Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: A chronic substance user presents with depression, hypersomnia, and cravings. History reveals that he has not used the substance for the past few days. Which substance is most likely involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cocaine withdrawal symptoms.

Cocaine withdrawal is a triphasic syndrome that presents after the sudden stoppage of chronic cocaine use. The phases are as follows - 

  1. Crash phase (9 hours-4 days): Anorexia, depression, excessive craving, hypersomnia, fatigue.
  2. Normal mood, anxiety, and anhedonia (4-7 days)
  3. Extinction phase (7-10 days): Absence of withdrawal symptoms but increased susceptibility to relapse.

Treatment for withdrawal includes bromocriptine and amantadine. They are useful in reducing cocaine cravings.

Other options:

Option A: Shakes, hallucinations, and agitation are symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. They occur 12-24 hours following alcohol intake. Other features include nausea, vomiting, malaise, anxiety, depression, and headache. 

Delirium tremens begin 72 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is due to the long-continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in chronic alcoholics due to temporary excess, sudden withdrawal of alcohol, shock after receiving an injury, such as fracture of a bone, or from acute infection, such as pneumonia, influenza, erysipelas, etc.

Option C: Profuse sweating, diarrhea, and piloerection (gooseflesh) are symptoms of opioid withdrawal. They are associated with nausea, vomiting, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, muscle cramps, and generalized body aches. These symptoms manifest about 12-24 hours after the stoppage and recede within 7-10 days of last use.

Option D: Synesthesia or seeing smells and hearing colors and flashback phenomenon (emotional and psychological experiences of the previous LSD) are features of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Other features include dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, mood changes, visual hallucinations, alterations in time perceptions, vision, and hearing. Side effects are psychosis, depression, panic attacks, and schizophrenic episodes.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the classical symptoms of measles?
questions.solution:
The classical symptoms of measles include cough, coryza and conjunctivitis.

The measles virus has an incubation period of 7-18 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots (Bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth). This is followed by a maculopapular rash after the fourth day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

The image below shows the characteristic rashes and the koplik spots seen in measles.

The cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

The image given below shows the Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

The diagnosis is mainly made clinically but a serological demonstration of IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies is also used. Complications are pneumonia, croup, tracheitis, etc. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Measles can be prevented by active immunization. Live attenuated vaccine is given subcutaneously except for immunocompromised and pregnant women. According to WHO it requires at least 96% immunization coverage under one year of age for eradication.

Other options:

Option A: Mumps is caused by a paramyxovirus and spread by droplets and contact. It causes fever, malaise unilateral or bilateral parotitis. It also causes epididymal orchitis in males.

Option C: Chickenpox is caused by varicella zoster and spreads by contact and airborne. It has a prodrome of fever, malaise, anorexia, and headache which is followed by a rash in 1-2 days. It has pruritic, erythematous macules that first appear on the trunk and spread to the face and extremities, evolving into papules, vesicles, and pustules that become crusted. The below image shows multiple vesicular lesions on the trunk, which is suggestive of chickenpox.

Option D: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is caused by parvovirus B19 transmitted by airborne route. The prodromal consists of low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. An erythematous slapped cheeked rash that first appears on the face is characteristic.

The following image shows a slapped cheek appearance seen in Erythema infectiosum (Fifth Disease):

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Erythema infectiosum

Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl came for a health checkup. She doesn't go to school. Which government program will benefit her?
questions.solution:
Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK), an ambitious initiative, launched under the National Health Mission (NHM) launched envisages early screening and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years. It aims at the universal screening of the 4 ‘D’s, i.e. Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Developmental delays, including disabilities, that would lead to early identification, timely management, and ultimately a reduction in morbidity, mortality, and lifelong disability in children.

 Defects:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Down’s syndrome
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Talipes
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract, congenital deafness, congenital heart disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

Deficiencies:

  • Anemia, especially severe anemia
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Severe acute malnutrition
  • Goiter

Diseases:

  • Scabies, fungal infections, and eczema
  • Otitis media
  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Reactive airway disease
  • Dental caries
  • Convulsive disorders

Developmental delays and disabilities:

  • Vision, hearing, and neuromotor impairment
  • Motor, cognitive and language delay
  • Autism
  • Learning disorder
  • Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder

Other options:

Option B: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), whose aim is to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

Option C: Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram includes training of doctors, nurses, and ANMs for essential newborn care, early diagnosis, and case management of common ailments of children.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN) previously known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme, is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides one hot cooked meal in Government and Government-aided Schools

Under the Scheme, there is a provision of hot cooked meal to all preschool children and also to children of classes I to VIII. The scheme is implemented across the country covering all the eligible children without any discrimination of gender and social class.

questions.text:
ORS solution facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?

ORS-Oral Rehydration Solution
questions.solution:
Oral rehydration solution (ORS) facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter 1(SGLT 1). In a child with diarrhoea, when ORS is given, there is coupled absorption of sodium and glucose through SGLT-1.

Glucose transport may be active or passive:

  • Active transport of glucose takes place through SGLT-1 and SLGT-2.
  • SGLT 1 helps in glucose absorption in the small intestine and renal tubules.
  • SGLT 2 (Option B) primarily facilitates glucose absorption in the renal tubules.
  • Passive absorption of glucose occurs through facilitated diffusion. This is carried out by glucose transporters GLUT 1 to 7. 

Other options :

Option C: GLUT4 is the carrier for insulin-mediated uptake of glucose into muscle and adipose tissue.

Option D: The sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), also known as the sodium-calcium transporter, is a crucial membrane protein that helps maintain cellular calcium homeostasis by facilitating the exchange of sodium (Na⁺) and calcium (Ca²⁺) ions across the plasma membrane.

questions.text: A child has complaints of hematuria, mild sensorineural hearing loss, and eye defects. His renal biopsy on electron microscopy showed a basket-weave appearance. What type of collagen is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hematuria, mild sensorineural hearing loss, eye defects, and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) in electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome. It is a glomerular basement membrane disease that is caused due to mutations in the type IV collagen genes.

The GBM in Alport syndrome shows irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa, often producing the basket-weave appearance.

It is hereditary and can be inherited as an X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive disorder. However, the most common mode of inheritance of classic Alport syndrome is X-linked. Therefore, male relatives tend to be affected as in this case. 

Clinically, the classic variant of Alport syndrome presents with hematuria due to nephritis that slowly progresses to end-stage renal disease, an anterior lenticonus, and a mild, non-progressive sensorineural hearing loss that usually involves higher frequencies. Other eye findings include lens dislocation, corneal dystrophy, and posterior cataracts.

The investigation involves biopsy and histopathologic examination which includes the following findings-

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal until late in the disease course. End-stage renal disease can show histological features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
  • Electron microscopy: Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa producing a distinctive basket-weave appearance.
  • Immunofluorescence: No deposits.

Image: Basket-weave appearance in Alport syndrome

Other options:

Option B: Deficiency of type I collagen synthesis causes osteogenesis imperfecta. It presents as postnatal fractures, blue sclera, lax joints, fragile skeleton, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and normal stature.

Option C: Deficiency of type III collagen is associated with vascular type IV Ehler-Danlos syndrome. It presents as thin easily bruisable skin, arterial and uterine rupture, and joint hyperextensibility.

Option D: Deficiency of type II collagen is associated with skeletal dysplasia, and ocular findings such as lens subluxation, cataract, myopia, etc, hearing impairment, and facial features.

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. An abnormality in the development of which pharyngeal arch is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Treacher Collins syndrome that results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. They are:

Treacher Collins syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) - Autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by:

  • Craniofacial bone defects - Involves mandible, maxilla, and zygomatic arches, causing micrognathia.
  • Ear defects - Involves the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
  • Eye defects - Down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas

Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) - Caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 

  • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate.
  • The primary defect is poor growth of the mandible (micrognathia). As a consequence of this, the tongue is posteriorly placed (glossoptosis), Additionally, the tongue remains in between the palatal shelves and they fail to fuse (cleft palate)
