questions.text: Which health planning committee proposed the 3 million plan?
questions.solution:
The 3 million plan was proposed by the Bhore Committee.

It proposed to set up the following in the long term:

  • Primary health units with 75-bedded hospitals for each 10,000 to 20,000 population
  • Secondary units with 650 beds
  • District hospitals with 2,500 beds

 As a short-term measure, it was proposed that each PHC must cater to 40,000 people and have:

  • 2 medical officers, 4 public health nurses, 1 nurse
  • 4 midwives, 4 dais, 2 sanitary inspectors, 2 health assistants
  • 1 pharmacist
  • 15 other class IV employees

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with nausea, vomiting, and irrational behaviour two days after swimming in a freshwater lake during a camping trip. He is diagnosed with rapidly progressing meningoencephalitis and, unfortunately, passes away soon after. What is the most likely cause of his illness?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is most likely due to the organism Naegleria fowleri, a pathogenic free-living amoeba. 

It mostly affects previously healthy young adults or children. The infection sets in acutely following swimming or diving in ponds or other warm, freshwater bodies. The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.

They are free-living amoeba and exist in three forms - cyst, ameboid trophozoite form, and flagellate trophozoite form.

The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis or primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Clinically, patients present with anosmia during the incubation period. Following this, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, neck stiffness, ataxia, seizures, and coma. It is fatal in the majority of cases and death usually occurs within one week.

Microscopic analysis of CSF will reveal motile amoeboid trophozoites.

Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B, which is the drug of choice. 

Other options-

Option B: Acanthamoeba is also a free-living amoeba. These organisms may also cause granulomatous amebic encephalitis, an infection of the brain and spinal cord. It usually occurs in immunocompromised patients and the incubation period and course of illness are typically slow. These features are in contrast to this patient's acute presentation and rapid deterioration, thereby suggesting another diagnosis.

Option C: Cryptosporidium species are implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. 

Option D: Entamoeba Histolytica is intestinal amoebae that are transmitted fecally. They are implicated in amoebic colitis and amoebic liver abscesses.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targeted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shows a mosquito with a horizontal body and no stripes on the wings suggestive of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: Which of the following processes does not occur in muscles?
questions.solution:
Ketogenesis occurs in the liver and not in the muscles. Muscles can use ketone bodies for energy, especially during prolonged fasting or intense exercise, but they do not produce them.

Ketogenesis occurs primarily in the mitochondria of liver cells. Fatty acids are brought into the mitochondria via carnitine palmitoyltransferase (CPT-1) and then broken down into acetyl CoA via beta-oxidation. Two acetyl-CoA molecules are converted into acetoacetyl-CoA via the enzyme thiolase; this is also known as acetyl coenzyme A acetyltransferase (ACAT). Acetoacetyl-CoA is converted to HMG-CoA via the enzyme HMG-CoA synthase. HMG-CoA lyase then converts HMG-CoA to acetoacetate. Acetoacetate can be converted to either acetone through non-enzymatic decarboxylation or to beta-hydroxybutyrate via beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase.

Other options :

Option A: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which can then be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and enter glycolysis for energy production.

Option C: Glycogenesis is the synthesis of glycogen from glucose molecules, allowing for the storage of glucose as glycogen for future energy needs.

Option D: Lipolysis is the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol, which can be utilized for energy production through fatty acid oxidation.

Related Pearl: Ketogenesis

questions.text:
The section which lays down the punishment for the offence of rape is:

BNS-Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita
questions.solution:
Section 64 BNS (376 IPC) lays down the punishment for the offence of rape. 

Section 64 (1) of the BNS(Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita) outlines the punishment for rape and section 64 (2) outlines the punishment for rape in custody/rape by a person in a position of authority or trust.

Other options :

Option A : Section 63 BNS (375 IPC) defines rape.

Option C : Section 70 BNS (376D IPC) defines gang rape and lays down the punishment for the same. The people who commit this act shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than twenty years, which may extend to imprisonment for life, and with a fine.

Option D : Section 74 BNS (354 IPC) deals with assault or use of criminal force on a woman with the intent to outrage her modesty.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman reports experiencing intermittent epigastric pain, which worsens after eating, for the past 7 months. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the epigastric region. The urease breath test is positive. A drug designed to remove which mineral from urease could potentially alleviate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the clinical features and positive urease test are suggestive of peptic ulcer disease caused by Helicobacter pylori. Urease enzyme produced by H. pylori contains nickel ions at its core, which act as a cofactor and promote the maturation of the enzyme. Hence drugs engineered to remove nickel can disrupt urease activity, thereby impairing the survival of H. pylori and reducing its pathogenic effects.

Nickel is also found in methyl-coenzyme M reductase (MCR) involved in methanogenesis. 

H. pylori is a gram-negative, motile bacillus that exclusively resides in the human gastric mucus. It has a unique feature of producing urease that converts urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, helping the bacteria survive in the acidic environment of the stomach.

H.pylori causes chronic superficial gastritis on long-term colonisation while few people develop peptic ulceration, gastric adenocarcinoma, and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. Current treatment regimens consist of a proton-pump inhibitor (omeprazole) and two or three antimicrobial agents given for 10–14 days.  

Other options:

Option A: Manganese can be found in metalloenzymes like isocitrate dehydrogenase, arginase, and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.

Option B: Chromium potentiates the action of insulin in patients with impaired glucose tolerance, presumably by increasing insulin receptor-mediated signalling. 

Option D: Selenium is a component of glutathione reductase and de-iodinase. Selenium deficiency can lead to thyroid dysfunction, cardiomyopathies, and immune dysfunction.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with a history of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress. An X-ray of the neonate is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of frothiness and respiratory distress and an X-ray showing a nasogastric (NG) tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas are suggestive of esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

Longitudinal furrow separates the trachea from the esophagus during development. Deviation or altered growth in this septum results in the formation of an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea called a tracheoesophageal fistula. It is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.

The newborn has excessive drooling and frothing soon after birth. On feeding, the baby develops choking and cyanosis. Regurgitation of secretion and feed through the fistulous tract into the lungs results in aspiration pneumonia.

Type C consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF is the commonest. Here the air enters into stomach causing gastric distention which is seen as an air bubble. There is an inability to pass an NG tube for more than 7-10 cm, and a coiling in the proximal esophagus helps in the diagnosis.

Other options

Option A - Transient tachypnea of newborn is due to delayed clearance of lung fluid. They have tachypnea with minimal or no respiratory distress. Chest X-ray may show hyper-expanded lung fields, prominent vascular marking and prominent interlobar fissure.

Option B: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia occurs because of the failure to close the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Intestinal loops enter the thorax and compress the developing lung causing pulmonary hypoplasia. They present with respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray would show multiple air-filled spaces in the thorax, a shift of mediastinum, and the absence of an outline of the left diaphragm.

Option D: Respiratory distress syndrome/Hyaline membrane disease occurs primarily in premature infants due to a deficiency of surfactant in the alveoli. Clinical features include tachypnea, retractions, grunting, cyanosis, and decreased air entry. X-ray shows reticulogranular pattern, ground glass opacity, low lung volume, air bronchogram, and white-out lungs in severe disease.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: Following the recovery of a beheaded skull bone by the police, the relatives of a missing person want to confirm his identity. Which of the following techniques can be used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person?
questions.solution:
The technique used to figure out a person's identity using the beheaded skull bone and photograph of the person is superimposition.

The superimposition technique is applied to the skull to determine whether it belongs to the person in the photograph. The following points can be used for comparisons such as the eyes, nasion, prosthion, zygomas, lower border of the nose, supraorbital ridges, lower border of the zygomas, angle of the jaw, external auditory meatus, teeth and the lower border of the upper jaw.

Other options:

Option B: Anthropometry is based on the principle that the skeletal dimensions do not change after the age of 21 years and the variation in the size of the different parts to one another. Descriptive data such as the color of the hair, eyes, complexion, and body marks are recorded. Body measurements are estimated such as height, anteroposterior diameter of head and trunk, the span of outstretched arms, the length of the left middle finger, left little finger, left forearm, left foot, length, and breadth of right ear, and color of left iris from the photographs. 

Option C: DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis is done to detect DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene. DNA fingerprinting uses restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLPs) or Polymerase chain reaction(PCR) to identify a person's unique pattern of DNA. 

Option D: Cheiloscopy is also known as lip printing. Here, the fissures and grooves on the lip characteristic of a person are examined.

questions.text: An elderly male patient with a history of heart failure, currently on a cardiac glycoside, presents to the emergency department with severe vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbances, and restlessness. His ECG shows ventricular bigeminy. Which heart failure medication is most likely responsible for this acute presentation?
questions.solution:
In this given clinical scenario, with ECG findings showing ventricular bigeminy, digoxin is the drug that would have likely caused this acute presentation suggestive of digitalis toxicity.  

Digoxin has a very low therapeutic index. Digitalis toxicity can manifests as any type of arrhythmias (atrial tachycardia with AV block is classic) as well as produce severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It also causes visual disturbances such as blurring or yellowing of vision.  

Treatment includes cessation of digoxin administration followed by intravenous potassium in the case of tachyarrhythmia, intravenous lidocaine for ventricular arrhythmia, and intravenous propranolol for supraventricular arrhythmias. Digoxin antibody (Fab fragment) is used in severe cases of digitalis toxicity.

Digoxin is the only cardiac glycoside that is in clinical use. It has a positive inotropic action and helps the failing heart to regain back some of its contractile power and reduces heart rate as well. Digoxin acts by inhibiting the NA+K+ATPase enzyme which causes an increase in intracellular calcium leading to increased contractility and a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance and heart rate. 

The major route of digoxin elimination is by P-glycoprotein (efflux transporter). Drug interactions with amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, etc can decrease digoxin clearance and possibly cause digitalis toxicity. 

Other options: 

Option A: Lidocaine is commonly used as a local anesthetic. It has anti-arrhythmic properties and is used to suppress ventricular tachycardia that is caused by digitalis toxicity.

Option C: Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker and is used in heart failure. It acts by arteriolar and venodilatation causing reduction of afterload and preload. It has adverse effects such as headache, dizziness, weakness, and fetopathic potential.

Option D: Levosimendan is an inotropic drug as well as a phosphodiesterase inhibitor. It is primarily used in acute on chronic decompensated heart failure as a short-term therapy. The most common side effect is hypotension.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with complaints of bleeding gums. Blood investigations showed iron deficiency anemia.  Which of the following vitamin deficiencies do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Dietary deficiency of vitamin C can lead to scurvy which can manifest as microcytic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. It is mainly required for the hydroxylation of prolyl and lysyl residues of collagen reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. It also facilitates the absorption of iron by reducing it from a ferric to a ferrous state.

Hence, vitamin C deficiency leads to defective collagen synthesis, fragile blood vessels, and iron deficiency anemia. Other clinical features of scurvy include spongy gums, loose teeth, swollen joints, subcutaneous hemorrhage, and bone fractures.

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below. What is the nature of the data seen here?
questions.solution:
In the image, the tail of the distribution is towards the positive direction and thus it is a positively skewed or right-skewed distribution.

To further understand and correlate the data representation with that of a corresponding box and whisker plot, have a look at the following images:

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. Which of the following tumor markers are most likely to be expressed by immunohistochemical studies of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with haemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: You are a resident observing an intern resuscitate a newborn in the labor room. After half a minute of bag and mask ventilation by the intern, the infant is still pale and hypoxic. What would you advise the intern?

choices.text: Readjust the mask and head position

questions.solution:
The next step in this newborn with ineffective bag and mask ventilation (BMV) is to readjust the mask and reposition the head.

Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) by BMV is given when infants fail to breathe at birth. The infant's neck is slightly extended to make sure the airway is open. The care provider is at the head end of the baby and a face mask of appropriate size is chosen to cover the mouth and nose. The adequacy of ventilation is indicated by visible chest rise and when normal chest rise is observed, ventilation should be started.

Increasing heart rate; spontaneous respiration; and improvement in color, saturation, and tone help to assess the infant's improvement.

When there is no improvement after 30 seconds of BMV(according to Nelson's textbook of pediatrics) or 15 seconds of BMV (according to the Indian Association of Pediatrics), ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows - MRSOPA

  • Mask has to be reapplied 
  • Reposition the infant's head
  • Suction the secretions
  • Open the mouth
  • Increase the Pressure
  • Use an Alternative airway.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding developmental milestones.
  1. Object permanence is achieved at 1 year of age
  2. Binocular vision is well established by 4 months of age
  3. Vocalization not attained at 7 months of age is a red flag sign
  4. Sitting without support not attained at 1 year of age is a red flag sign
  5. Lifting the head on ventral suspension is not attained at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct regarding developmental milestones. 

Binocular vision, the ability to use both eyes together, begins at approximately 6 weeks and becomes well-established by 4 months. By 6 months, children start adjusting their positions to keep track of objects of interest, and by 1 year, they can follow rapidly moving objects.

When an important developmental milestone crosses the upper age limit to develop, it is considered a red flag sign. The upper age limit to attain vocalization as a language milestone is 6 months. The upper age limit to attain sitting without support as a gross motor milestone is 10 months. A child needs to be evaluated for developmental delay if they do not attain the milestones by this age. 

On ventral suspension, a child is unable to lift the head until 4 weeks of age. At 6 weeks, the child momentarily holds the head in a horizontal plane. By 8 weeks, they can maintain this position well. By 12 weeks, they can lift their head above the horizontal plane.

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when it is not seen. It starts to develop by 7 months of age as an infant persists in searching for lost objects. It is well established by 9 months of age (statement 1). 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A 1 week-old neonate was brought to the tertiary care hospital with the following findings and a head circumference less than -3SD. The mother informs that she has been taking a drug for a neurological condition, for the last 4 years. Which of the following drugs is likely to be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of an intrauterine growth restriction, with a history of drug intake for neurological conditions and the image showing a cleft lip, the most likely drug implicated is phenytoin.

The mother would have been taking phenytoin during pregnancy which can cross the placenta and cause fetal hydantoin syndrome as shown in the image.

In fetal hydantoin syndrome, the child may be small at birth with increased hair on the body and face facial features include a flat nasal bridge, an underdeveloped vertical groove in the center of the upper lip (philtrum), malformed ears, downward-slanting eyes, which are spaced widely (hypertelorism), strabismus, ptosis and epicanthic folds. Other features include microcephaly and growth deficiencies like underdeveloped fingers and toes, and malformed nails.

The child would have varying degrees of developmental delay and the risk of an affected child having neurological deficits, cleft lip, cleft palate, and heart defects is very high. They may be at increased risk of the occurrence of benign or malignant tumors, such as neuroblastoma and Wilms tumor.

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome 

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

Other options:

Option A: Maternal use of Lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly where there is downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle and macrosomia.

Options B and D: Levetiracetam and Lamotrigine are relatively safe in pregnancy and do not seem to cause neural tube defects.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
questions.solution:
The upward extension of the thyroid swelling is prevented by the attachment of sternothyroid to the thyroid cartilage.

The thyroid gland can only enlarge anteriorly, posteriorly, laterally, and inferiorly. The superior extension of thyroid swelling is limited by two muscles namely: sternothyroid and sternohyoid.

Other options:

Option A: Pretrachial fascia encloses the thyroid gland and is attached to the larynx. This attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

Option C: Thyrohyoid membrane is a fibro-elastic ligament, which arises from the superior margin of the thyroid cartilage, and gets attached to the hyoid bone. It facilitates the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.

Option D:  Ligament of Berry, also called suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

questions.text: You conduct a study to determine the association between computer use and visual impairment and get a correlation coefficient of +0.4. Which of the following scattergrams best represents your findings?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario having a correlation coefficient of +0.4 shows a positive weak correlation and the scattergram that best represents this finding is graph number 2.

Correlation is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer). The correlation coefficient (denoted by r) is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • Correlation coefficients greater than ± 0.5 are considered strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.
  • Correlation coefficients between 0 and ± 0.5 are regarded as weak.

The sign indicates the direction of the correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated. This means that the high value of one variable is associated with a high value in another. An example is an association between salt intake and blood pressure readings.
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated. A high value of one variable such as cigarette consumption is associated with a low value of another variable such as life expectancy.

The relationship between two correlated variables can be represented graphically in the form of a scattergram. Each point represents one observation including both the variables and so would be equal to the sample size. 

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient, while its direction is indicated by the sign. The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below.

Examples:

Positive Correlation (+r): High salt intake is associated with high blood pressure.

Negative Correlation (-r): Increase in smoking of tobacco is associated with a decrease in life expectancy. 

No correlation (r=0): Height of a person and his blood group.

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson product-moment correlation
    It is used for data that have continuous intervals like salt intake vs BP to find a linear relationship.
  2. Spearman rank-order correlation
    It is used for data that have discrete ordered intervals like socioeconomic status vs parity to find a linear or non-linear relationship.

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable. For example - If a study finds a correlation (r) of 0.60 between smoking and life expectancy, it could be concluded that (0.6)2 = 0.36, or 36% of the variation in life expectancy in this study is accounted for by smoking.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with chronic constipation was prescribed a stimulant purgative after she failed to respond to laxatives. Which of the following drugs is likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a stimulant purgative drug that acts as a 5HT4 receptor agonist. It facilitates cholinergic neurotransmission and is approved for use in women with chronic constipation in whom laxatives fail to provide adequate relief.

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran, Psyllium/Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin (option D)
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium pico sulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide (option A)
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate 
    • Sod. pot. tartrate
    • Lactulose (option B)

questions.text: Thiamine acts as a coenzyme for all of the following multi-enzyme complexes involved in oxidative decarboxylation reactions, except ______.
questions.solution:
Thiamine is the coenzyme for all the given multi-enzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions, except isocitrate dehydrogenase.

Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme in the citric acid cycle that catalyzes the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. It uses Mg2+ or Mn2+ ions as a coenzyme.

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) serves as the coenzyme for three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions like,

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase in carbohydrate metabolism (Option A)
  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle (Option B).
  • Branched-chain keto-acid dehydrogenase, involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine (Option C).

TPP also serves as the cofactor of transketolase in HMP shunt.

questions.text: While carrying out a postmortem analysis of a victim, which of the following features will be consistent with an antemortem burn?

choices.text: Dry, hard and yellow blister base
Absent line of redness around wound

questions.solution:
The feature consistent with an antemortem burn is presence of carboxyhemoglobin in blood.

The presence of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood is highly suggestive of death due to antemortem burns. A blood hemoglobin saturation of >10% with carbon monoxide is indicative of antemortem smoke inhalation.

This is in contrast to postmortem burns, wherein carboxyhemoglobin levels are not elevated as it is not possible for the gas to diffuse through the skin or be otherwise absorbed by a dead body.  

Other options:

Option A: Dry, hard, and yellow blister base is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the inflamed, red base of blisters seen in antemortem burns.

Option B: Absent line of redness around burn wounds is seen in postmortem burns. This vital reaction, termed red flare, is present in antemortem burns.

Option C: Reduced enzymatic activity around the wound is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the significant increase in enzyme activity (cathepsin, aminopeptidase, alkaline phosphatase) as seen in an antemortem burn.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does V/Q = infinity occur?

choices.text: When there is foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When volume of the lung equals dead space
When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal
When PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.solution:
VA /Q= infinity means that there is no exchange of O2 & CO2, which means the volume of the lung equals dead space and the physiological effort of breathing is wasted. 

VA represents the ventilation in alveoli and Q represents the blood flow through the alveolus. The ratio of VA and Q explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow. The ventilation-perfusion ratio is considered normal if there is an equal amount of blood flow & ventilation through the alveolus.

VA /Q ratio is infinity when:

  • There is adequate ventilation but no perfusion.
  • No exchange of gases ( O2 and CO2 )through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  • The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  • Partial pressures of the O2 and CO2 are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively (Option D).

Other options :

Option A: V/Q ratio is zero when ventilation is zero like in case of foreign body obstruction.

Option C: The ventilation-perfusion ratio is considered normal when the O2 and CO2 ratio is equal (equal amount of blood flow & ventilation through the alveolus).

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed an infection. Blood analysis revealed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Filgrastim is the drug used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF(granulocyte-colony stimulating factor), that stimulates CFU-G(colony-forming unit- granulocyte) to increase neutrophil production. It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion. It is indicated in: 

  • The treatment of severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and high-dose cancer chemotherapy.
  • The treatment of severe congenital neutropenias.
  • The treatment of neutropenia of patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine.

Important adverse reactions include bone pain, local skin reaction, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

Other options:

Option A: Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the management of immune thrombocytopenic purpura(ITP). 

Option B: Oprelvekin is a recombinant human IL-11. It stimulates hematopoiesis. It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies. Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.

Option D: Epoetin alfa is a recombinant human erythropoietin analogue that stimulates red blood cell production. It is used in the treatment of anaemias associated with surgery, chronic kidney disease, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, prematurity, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: In a community of 5000, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people. The number of pregnant females is?
questions.solution:
The number of pregnant females is 165.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 30 x 5000/1000 = 150 

Step 3: We should also consider the pregnancy wastage i.e 10% of total live births =10 x 150/100=15 (since some pregnancies may not result in live birth i.e abortions and stillbirths, a correction factor of 10% is to be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies)

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live birth + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant presented with complaints of irritability and inability to walk. Physical examination was notable for hypotonia and nystagmus. A brain MRI was suggestive of metachromatic leukodystrophy. Which of the following enzymes are likely to be deficient?
questions.solution:
Metachromatic leucodystrophy occurs due to the deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is a serious condition and causes death within 5-6 years in early-onset form.

Clinical manifestations of the diseases can be categorized by the age of disease onset:

Late infantile-onset: Occurs in children < 30 months of age. Typically, early milestones are met, followed by a progressive regression of motor skills, ataxia, dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, extensor plantar posturing, and optic atrophy. Accounts for a majority of the cases.
 
Juvenile onset: Occurs between 30 months and puberty. Early milestones are met, followed by psychomotor regression, intellectual decline in the form of dropped school performance, behavioural difficulties, and personality changes.
 
Adult-onset: This type shows neurocognitive and neuropsychiatric difficulties. Patients may have dysesthesias like peripheral neuropathy, psychosis, schizophrenia, or seizures. 

Other options

Option A: In Krabbe’s disease due to a deficiency of the enzyme β-galactosidase, galactosylceramide accumulates in oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This accumulation causes the formation of globoid cells (hematogenous often-multinucleated macrophages containing undigested galactosylceramide). 

Option C: Niemann-Pick disease is caused due to sphingomyelinase deficiency leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin. Clinical features include mental retardation and hepatosplenomegaly.

Option D: Farber disease constitutes a deficiency of acid ceramidase which leads to the accumulation of sphingosine ceramide. The clinical features include Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, and mental retardation. It is fatal in early life.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about systematic reviews?
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is not always performed in systematic reviews. 

Steps of a Systematic Review:

  • A systematic review is the process of locating and synthesizing the research on a particular question using organized, transparent, and replicable procedures.
  • It ranks high in the hierarchy of evidence in medicine.
  • The research question formulated is always focussed.
  • The literature on studies is always found and appraised after criteria of eligibility are established.
  • Meta-analysis is usually done in a systematic review but not always.
